Review: This is one of the best games ever made and the only reason it is not regarded as such is that it is not very accessible. I can imagine many critics have started Terraria, played for some hours trying to figure it out, and put it away. Very often, critics have drawn misguided conclusions that Terraria resembles Minecraft (or is a Minecraft clone), but in fact nothing could be further from the truth. Terraria is a procedurally generated sandbox survival metroidvania. Learning curve is steep, the game is hard and often requires you to consult to wikis and guides (even more so than the Souls series) but once you gain control of the game mechanics, you will find a very deep, hard core gem. Don‚Äôt let its eye-candy graphics fool you‚Ä¶  You are dropped into a world surrounded by many dangers. Initially, you are expected to make your first shelter, first weapon and just survive. This is the very core of the whole game. In order to beat stronger creatures, you need better weapons for which you need better crafting material. To get better crafting material, you need to mine deep into the earth, which leads you to find secret chests, face gazillion creatures including ‚Äúbosses‚Äù. Boss fights not only require skill, but also need you to have the weapons, armors, potions, items necessary to beat them. Last, but not the least, there are plenty of events such as Halloween, Christmas, Pirate Invasion etc. with their own unique bosses and loots.  While you are working on mining for better tools, armors, weapons to be able to beat stronger enemies, you also need to keep expanding your ‚Äúshelter‚Äù. A chair, ceiling and door is not sufficient any longer. You need to keep building new rooms to have room for new crafting centers and chests (for inventory). Every new room invites a new NPC to your shelter who can be crucial in your quest to beat the world of terraria, whether they sell unique items or provide healing.  Being a true sandbox game, you can also ignore progression and spend hundreds of hours just building. Your limit to what you can build and how you can customize it is your imagination. People at Terraria subreddit still manage to amaze me with their creativity and sometimes totally mind-blowing architecture.  Whether you choose to play it as a metroidvania or as a sandbox 2d Minecraft, you will love Terraria. In my opinion, it is one of the best games ever made.  Buy it full price. Developers are still updating content and supporting the game after all these years (without any paid DLCs whatsoever), they really deserve some support.

Review: Terraria is one of the best survival sandbox games to date. It might be relatively old now, but it's truly a great game to pick up to play alone or with friends.  This is the game I end up coming back to from time to time, as it provides lots of fun and many different things to do. Build, craft, fight, gather materials or items - it's all up to you. It's even more fun when you get into it with friends. The amount of content this game has to offer is enormous; fights are exciting, building is fun and highly enjoyable, finding various items is always nice. You can have fun things such as mounts and pets, or even a sword that shoots cats. Generally a super fun game with many possibilities.  Summary:  - LOTS of content. - Can be enjoyable even if you want to play alone. - A lot of stuff to do and places to explore. - Different content difficulties. - Might be confusing at the start, but gets super fun when you figure out things. - Huge amount of various in game items. - Soundtrack is one of the most enjoyable I've heard. - Plenty of different NPCs that will end up invading your home. - Possiblities for building are endless. It's very enjoyable and you can experiment with all kinds of blocks and decor.  Overall, this is an amazing sandbox game, with pretty much endless possibilities, and I highly recommend it!

Review: Terraria's relevance and uniqueness are well beyond words. It's one of the very few sandbox survival games that manage to build an entertaining and content-rich progression system while also keeping the player a desirable amount of freedom. Even repetitive tasks such as mining are fun thanks to how many hidden chests and mini-dungeons you can accidentally find.  From bosses to weapon variety, there's so much Terraria gets right that I feel safe to say all survival games should take inspiration from it somehow. Here's to all the hours of action-rich fun Terraria provided and is yet to provide.

Review: Terraria is an action-adventure sandbox game developed by Re-Logic.  üëã First impression  I've known about the game for a while, but I didn't want to try it because it had old graphics and people often compared it to Minecraft, but in the end it was well worth the experience.  ‚úîÔ∏èPros ‚ùåCons ‚Ä¢ Incredible amount of different weapons and classes  ‚Ä¢ Beautiful 2D world ‚Ä¢ No cons for this masterpiece   Ah ... What an adventure. You start by cutting down a tree and building a small rectangle for your first npc friend in the game, and you end up fighting aliens, crazy cultists, and other mad things. I thought I was getting into a relaxing game that wouldn't bother me at all, but ... well, I can say that there were some bosses who got me on my toes.  ‚Ä¢  Crafting in this game is the thing that made the biggest and best impression to me. There are so many things you can do other things with ... When you're at the beginning of the game, it can swallow you. The most important thing is not to worry about using the internet in this game. The right way to play is with 25 tabs in Google Chrome open at the same time while trying to find the right item to craft.  ‚Ä¢  At the beginning of the game, it is very important to build platforms that can be used to avoid the attacks of the bosses. I haven't played the game before this last patch, but as far as I've seen, videos showing people defeating bosses in an "easy" way with minimal movement are now updated and not working, so your mechanics will play a key role in your playthrough. Here may be the time to mention that I personally played in Expert and I was not alone, but –∞ duo with a friend of mine.   After the last patch of the game there are a total of 104 achievements. A lot of them can be completed while preparing for bosses, end game, etc. Others want you to craft an item or do something, not that hard. In general, the achievements are not so difficult and can also be a good guide when you are wondering what to do. However, there is one achievement that will haunt you. HELPER MINION is the name of this nightmare. Remember this name and when you get into the game and have only this achievement left, come back to this review and leave a comment. The day I write this review I have 170 hours in the game and I am on quest number 158. Almost there, buds.    Honestly, I haven't tried the game in classic mode, but in expert mode it's not that easy, so I don't want to think about how it will be in master mode. However, if you do not have much time and just want to relax in the game, there is a mod–µ for that. It was added in the latest patch 1.4 and is called journey mode. There a lot of things are made much easier and non-committal. In short, the game is as difficult as the player wants it to be.   The game is as beautiful as 2D graphics allow it to be. I find many of the things that can be found in the world of to be quite sweet and beautiful.   has over eighty music tracks across every version of the game. Each one will play and loop endlessly while the player is in a specific biome or while certain events are taking place. All the music in was composed by Scott Lloyd Shelly of Resonance Array. I didn't have to play music from YouTube at all, so I find the game's music good and fitting.   I had no problems at all.  Game tested on:   The game itself is cheap and definitely worth the full price, so if you think you want to play it a lot, don't hesitate and take it. Waiting for a discount is also not a bad idea to save some money, but be sure to take this game. For the time you can spend in it, this amount of money is negligible.

Review: Have you ever wanted to fight a giant eyeball that has teeth by using a laser cannon that you obtained from an alien invasion while riding your giant bee? Then this game is for you.  Have you ever wanted to drink water while drowning to restore health so that you don't drown? Then this game is for you.  Have you ever wanted to explore a vast underground land of ash and lava? Then this game is for you.  Have you ever wanted an arsenal of unique and fun weapons to use, each with their own weird and wacky abilities, from firing nyan cats to summoning ice dragons? Then this game is for you.  Have you ever wanted lore that is almost entirely up to interpretation? Then this game is for you.  Have you ever wanted to fight the moon itself? Well too bad they scrapped that idea.  BUT STILL...  Have you ever wanted to have a good time? Then this game is for you! Like, seriously. It's a fun game. Lots of replay value, too.

Review: This game has impacted my life in a way that I didn't think a video game could. This game is a work of art and having grown up with it for almost 9 years with almost 2,000 hours played, I can confidently say that I 100% recommend this game. The extremely satisfying progression throughout the game, the wonderful and cute pixel art, the limitless replay value, and of course not to mention the insane bosses are just a few things that make this game stand unchallenged above any other game I've ever played. The system of different classes to choose from and hundreds of weapon types in each class make replaying the game not only fun but continuously satisfying as you continue to upgrade your weapons and armor and power. The tools for building and customizing your worlds allows for very unique and limitless construction. If you are looking for a game that you can dump hundreds of hours into with a WiKi you can get lost in and tons of secrets and items to uncover across multiple playthroughs, then look no further than Terraria.  Thank you to ReLogic for crafting such a masterpiece. :)

Review: Many people compare Terraria and Minecraft. And it's true, they are both voxel based mining games. However, Terraria tones down a lot of what Minecraft is in building and creativity, then makes up for it in the exciting combat and boss system. Don't get me wrong, you can still build interesting and exciting structures in Terraria, but the awe that some Minecraft creations can inspire is not found in Terraria. If you prefer emphasis on combat, boss battles, and equipment upgrades, but still want to be able to mine resources, create defenses, and terraform to your desire, Terraria is most certainly a good fit. There's a reason it's my most played game on Steam, and even as I write this, I have the game open on PSN to play with my friends.

Review: Terraria  Terraria is an amazingly fun to play 2D sandbox game. You start off with nothing but as you discover Terraria you notice how much is in this game.  Stats  Here are some general stats about Terraria to give you an idea of how impressive this game is.  Terraria contains:  - 2748 Items - 401 enemies - 76 potions - 69 swords - 34 bows - 30 guns - 21 bosses  As you can see Terraria contains a massive collection of fun.   You will start off by creating your character and creating your world. A nice feature to note is that you can have your character travel through multiple worlds while keeping their items. You will be thrust into a new world where you will have to gather resources and upgrade your arsenal. Night in Terraria is not as forgiving as Minecraft. After you survive you will continue to build up your personal collection while building a house. You will build a house so that random people can move in take up a room and rip you off with prices (jk not all prices are bad). Eventually you shall fight your first boss and bosses in Terraria will give you a run for your money so you better be prepared guys and gals.   Terraria is a fun game and even more fun with friends. Friends will help you out and make it easier to advance without dying.... too much :D. However if you do not feel like playing multiplayer singleplayer is just as fun. In single player you do not have to share your loot and your friends are incapable of stealing it, because it is singlepalyer.   Hardmode is a gamemode that Terraria automatically places you in after you beat The Wall of Flesh. In Hardmode you will meet new bosses and new enemies. You will find new materials and you will quickly realize every is much tougher and you need to quickly upgrade yourself.    + Smooth gameplay + Have not felt lag as of yet + character customization + huge amount of weapons + HARDCORE + entertaining for hours + huge amount of armour sets with special abilities   - a lot to grasp for a new player to Terraria (I dont think i can think of any more)   Terraria is an amazing 2D sandbox that tests you. This game has given me hours upon hours of fun and I would gladly recommend this game to anyone who has money in their wallet.

Review: Lets get into it shall we  Terraria, the game that makes you question your life choices more than a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure book on existentialism. I've spent more time in this pixelated wonderland than I have in the real world, and let me tell you, I regret nothing. My therapist might disagree, but what does she know about the joys of defeating pixelated bosses and building houses for NPCs who can't even say "thank you"?  With over 1200 hours logged, I can confidently say that Terraria is not just a game; it's a way of life. Forget sunshine and fresh air; I've got mushrooms and glowing ore to keep me company. Who needs friends when you have a loyal army of NPCs, each with their unique quirks and questionable fashion sense?  The variety in this game is mind-boggling. I mean, where else can you go from fighting a gigantic eye to crafting a rainbow gun that shoots unicorns? It's like a fever dream mixed with a dash of pure, unadulterated awesomeness. Terraria is the only place where you can go from feeling like a badass ninja to a master chef whipping up delicacies for your digital neighbors.  Speaking of neighbors, those NPCs are a special bunch. They move in, mooch off your hospitality, and somehow manage to get themselves killed by zombies every other night. It's like living in a retirement home for video game characters, and I love it. Who wouldn't want a nurse, a wizard, and a gun-slinging arms dealer as roommates?  The building aspect of Terraria is like playing with virtual Legos, only better. Sure, you could build a modest little house, but why stop there when you can create a floating island with a disco floor and lava waterfalls? My creativity knows no bounds, and neither does the game's ability to let me indulge in my architectural fantasies.  Terraria is the only game that has me questioning whether I've been spending too much time in the real world. Why go outside when I can explore the vast reaches of the underworld, battle mythical beasts, and collect rare artifacts? The real world doesn't have pixelated penguins, and that's a deal-breaker for me.  In conclusion, Terraria is not just a game; it's a lifestyle. I highly recommend it to anyone who values creativity, exploration, and the ability to ignore real-world responsibilities. With 1200+ hours under my belt, I can confidently say that Terraria is the reason my plants are dead, my dog is hungry, and my social life is practically nonexistent. And you know what? I wouldn't have it any other way. Five stars, two thumbs up, and a digital high five to the developers for creating this masterpiece. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a dungeon to raid and a virtual pet to feed.

Review: I NEVER expected this game to be as complex as it is!  At first I checked it out and was like "Yeah, this looks kinda like Minecraft in 2D" and I got into exploring the world, finding items and quickly realized there is WAY MORE than I expected.  In the beginning, farming wood and my first ore the game felt kinda slow, but once I looted some chests in the underground bioms and got some movement items for faster running or double jumps I was hooked for it. I built myself a base, gathered more npcs, crafted better weapons, armor and fought the first bosses. I died a lot but kept on going because it was so much fun.  I convinced a friend to buy the game and we explored the world together, progressed further into the bioms and found new gear everytime.  Do I recommend this game? Yes! Absolutely! If you don't mind the slow beginning and love exploring and experimenting with new stuff this game is for you!  PS: There are some pretty amazing items inthe game, if you get far enough! :D

Review: To commemorate the beta of Steam Reviews, as well as passing 1,000 hours in Team Fortress 2, it only makes sense that I finally write a recommendation for a game that has been close to my heart since the day I was first introduced to it: Terraria.  Terraria has proven to be a lot of fun to play, and has been one of my biggest video game time sinks in recent years because of it. Between lenient system requirements, a solid (albeit imbalanced, at times) combat system, a broad permittance for exploration and a wide selection of building decor, it's the type of game that strikes me as having something for everyone. Which is good, when you consider that it also has multiplayer. Even better when you get to the late game, which has a wide array of weapons, armors and tools to allow for a wide variety of specializations.  Building and exploration are strong points in favor of the game, but the gameplay mechanics are something I'd like to single out for praise. For a 2D game, its combat system has a lot of spectacle, and perhaps that's part of why I find it so charming. Hurting enemies--even those who are vastly inferior to you--feels good. It's satisfying to hear the hit sound on the more squishy enemies, and watch them explode into fine little chunks when they die. Ground movement could be better, but certain late game items give you the ability to dash and fly, which really expand how you can explore and fight. And with a wide selection of weapons, every player is bound to find a roster of tools, spells and fish-related artillery that fits their playstyle.  The game isn't without flaws, mind you. With the game's update history, the launch endgame now vastly differs from that of the current one. This has led to some balance and progression issues, the most glaring of which being how sluggish the early game feels. It worries me that the start of the game might dissuade some people from playing, when they might love what the late game has to offer. The game also has a bad habit of recycling mob AI with reskins, though this is averted by adjusting certain parameters and giving them unique abilities to hide the fact. Even though I have more to say about the shortcomings, there's just too much good in the game to stay mad about what effectively boils down to nitpicking.  Plus, it has hats. Any game that has a selection of hats gets brownie points.  Watch some trailers. Read some other reviews. If this looks like something you'd be interested in, then take it from me: give Terraria a chance. The game occasionally goes on sale for 75% off, so pick up a four pack for yourself and three friends. If I'm wrong, then I cost you a meal at Subway--not subliminal advertising--and I'm sorry. But if I'm right, then it'll be well worth the price. We're expected to pay $60 these days for a fulfilling gaming experience. This is one that'll run you $10, at most.

Review: I wanted to write this review after I spent enough time in the game and have gotten most of the achievements. So now that I‚Äôm about 109/115 achievements & 100 hours playtime, I feel I can finally give an adequate review.  I felt this game was hard to get into at the beginning but if you have someone help you through the first steps in learning the game play and crafting mechanics, it gets easier and more fun. It‚Äôs hard because at the start, you basically are some weak homeless dude and have to fight off slimes, collect and craft, materials build your own house before it gets dark (and pretty much do this for the entirety of the game but as you progress, you get to upgrade your gear and it gets easier). It sounds like a grind but it‚Äôs well-worth it. It‚Äôs somewhat satisfying to build yourself up from the beginning, from wood walls to the solar or vortex brick or something.  The coolest part of the game is the crafting and building aspects of it. There‚Äôs so many different types of materials, which you can make into various styles of brick or wall paper, even furniture (like balloon furniture). There‚Äôs so much customizability in how you can build your houses. There‚Äôs different environments or ‚Äúbiomes‚Äù so you build houses that are befitting of that specific biome and then you get NPC‚Äôs to move in. You can also collect weird paintings which you can decorate your houses with.  There‚Äôs different game modes too so if you want a challenge, you can play hardcore or if you just want to build, you can do journey mode which allows you to duplicate items so you don‚Äôt have to destroy your world mining it all. It‚Äôs one of those games where there‚Äôs no right way to play. Play how you want and play how you think is most fun. The music and the scenery in the game is also very pleasant, so it‚Äôs a very nice chill relax game. It‚Äôs nice solo and coop. 10/10 would recommend.          Notice, I didn't mention combat in my review. Eh, it's not my type of game combat wise but that's the beauty of this game. There's different game modes where you can choose what type of experience you want from the game. Some go for those hardcore challenge runs and I go for Journey mode because I love the buidling and crafting elements.

Review: Absolute classic. Whenever I play it feels like I'm progressing whether it be getting a new weapon, killing a boss or just building a really nice house for an NPC it always feels like I'm moving forward. Surprisingly, the game hasn't really seemed to show any signs of its age despite being almost 9 years old at this point. The music is fantastic especially during boss fights. Boss fights have a perfect challenge level when you do them with the intended gear and there are a whole lot of bosses to fight throughout the game. The game has a "halfway point" just when you start to feel established which really puts you back on your toes and creates an excellent dynamic without taking anything away from the player. Expert mode feels like a perfect challenge for people who have a lot of experience by adding new mechanics or just small buffs to each boss. Overall one of my favourite games of all time.

Review: 10/10 game. One of the best I've ever played, and there's a bunch of reasons why. Mostly though :  The developers - Relogic is a wonderful firm, that listens to its players. They've created a masterpiece and I thank them for it.  The community - This player base is friendly, creative and helpful. It's got everything. What more could you ask for?  The game in its entirety - Features cool worlds, items, animals, subtle story, and all of them come with consistently amazing updates. The scenery is beautiful (in its own way). Easter eggs and funny items is one of my favourite parts of the game. Never gets boring.  Every masterpiece has its own flaws, in this case :  Crossplay - Or should i say the lack there of.  Grinding - Some parts of the game are a bit too repetitive and annoying.  And notably :  The angler.  Thank you Relogic, My friends, And this game, for a 1000 hrs of joy.

Review: At first, this game may seem babyish: with an axe swinging all the way around and a sword looking little less than a porridge stirrer. You have a world, you can flourish and prosper but it is also a dangerous, hostile and menacing environment.  You create your first house: with a chair, table, walls and a background made from supposedly wood. You create your armour and a new sword and you set of in your quest for salvation. Later on, you gear up; and fight your first boss.  It gets harder over time and you have more and more responsibilities to keep your world on its feet, and don't let the bad thing happen...

Review: The amount of labor, love, and time that the developers have spent fine-tuning and improving this game is truly astounding. With over 5000 items, 28 bosses and minibosses, easy multiplayer access, and mod support all wrapped up into a $10 bundle with no extra microtransactions or DLC, Terraria is a masterpiece that large-scale game companies could only dream of making. A single playthrough can easily last you over 30+ hours, for most, that is barely the tip of the iceberg.  This is a game that you can play and replay multiple times and still discover new items and mechanics with each playthrough. Every new world is a new adventure, a new place for creativity, an escape from reality to let your inner imagination run loose. Nothing pushes or pressures you to rush through the game, it is a self-paced journey that, despite the many labels put onto it, has no real end. Some people play the game to find new items and accessories, others play to build the ideas that live in their minds, but no matter how you decide to play the game, there is something for everyone to enjoy. Relogic called the 1.4 update ‚ÄúJourney‚Äôs End,‚Äù but I think that, even now, it is just the beginning.  In addition to all of this, the multiplayer in this game is absolutely phenomenal. Playing, chatting, and enjoying the game with friends is an incredible experience*. The pacing of the game barely changes compared to single-player and the atmosphere and ideas that can run through your world can be incredible. Access to the steam workshop, a place where you can share your creations or see the creations of others, is also a great addition to the game**.   Unfortunately, no game can be perfect in every way, I do have a few minor issues with the game.  RNG: Most items in Terraria are commonly available throughout the game. However, a very select few are very Rng dependent and can often feel like a chore to grind for. Fortunately, most of these items are entirely optional such as the information accessories and some late-game boss drops. Summoner Class: There are 4 main fighting classes in the game, Melee, Ranger, Mage, and Summoner. The latter is a unique class that uses minions to fight for you. This is a fantastic concept, but it is very poorly executed due to the lack of variety of summoner weapons and armor. Master Mode is a new difficulty in Terraria that was added in the 1.4 update, which increases the difficulty of the game by tripling the monster‚Äôs health and damage‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs it. Other than a few extra cosmetic items, Master Mode is simply Expert Mode but with more enemy health. It doesn‚Äôt add anything new or interesting so it is usually best to just avoid it unless you are into that type of gameplay.  These are very minor flaws with the game and absolutely do not impact the overall gameplay or enjoyability at all. Terraria is one of the greatest gaming experiences I have had, the time I spent playing by myself and friends during the lockdown was definitely time well spent. If you are someone who enjoys building games, combat of all types, exploration, or just want a game that is a mixture of all of these, then I definitely recommend buying this game. If Relogic had made the updates cost money, then I absolutely would have paid, and the fact that they continue to add free updates to this game 10 years after its release just goes to show how much they care about their player and fanbase, and that is absolutely something I am willing to support.   * If you plan to start a multiplayer world with more than two people, I highly recommend playing on an expert mode world because of the modified boss drops. If you play on a normal world, then you will get boss drops equivalent to the boss drops of single-player, whereas an expert world‚Äôs boss drops are equivalent to the number of players on the world.   ** Terraria also has fantastic mod support, with the developers at Relogic just recently updating TModLoader to 1.4, and though I have never played modded Terraria, I have heard fantastic things about all kinds of community creations.   TL;DR Good game, you should buy

Review: Is exactly what it depicts on the trailer, and more  Calling Terraria a 2D clone of Minecraft is doing both games a disservice. Sure, Terraria shares the sandbox and building aspects, but it really shines in its exploring capabilities.  As many have commented before, the game has tons of exploring to do. Not just mining for better equipment, mind you, but also looking out for helpful NPCs, discovering secrets below (and above!), learning how to deal with the enemies, the terrain and the bosses. Preparing your fort against invasions, creating the perfect place to relax... and all of this is before Hardmode, where the real meat of the game lies.  Terraria is a bit obscure by design. It's meant to be taken as a world to explore, a world of unknowns. Finding new things, trying new strategies is the heart and soul of this game.  as of the time of writing this review, the developers have supported and expanded this game for 8 years now, without DLC or microtransactions BS. Think about that the next time you see an Early Access game rushed out.  Even if you pay full price for this game, you're getting one of the best games on Steam when it comes to price per hours played. Seriously, you're getting quite a bang for your buck here,

Review: A game developed and published by Re-Logic.  Terraria, an interesting title, where your imagination determines how far you can progress, and how much time you will pour into this game. A hollow world till you arrive, teeming with precious ores, and dark secrets. Fetid swamps and dry deserts. This game is definitely an endeavour, and it will soak up alot of your time as you try and reach the pinnacle of your characters limitations and how much you can construct. Often remarked as a "2D Minecraft" I always find this comparison woefully incorrect. Minecraft has a wide selection of enemies, which is similar, A wide array of ore and precious gems to mine, which is also similar. But from then one, Terraria leaves it dead in the water. An RPG experience, with substantial boss progression, Active try and retry game mechanics and spanning character classes, All inclusive of a massive crafting system, and wide assortment of things to collect and try. Anyways, I've praised it enough, lets get down to the review!  Graphics: Probably one of the weaker points of the game, Its still very vibrant and holds upto despite its 2011, Birthdate. This is mainly due to the pixelated graphics and 2D perspective of the game. Not alot to render, and not alot to process at any one time, Making it run very smoothly at any point in time, But also extremely limited due to there not being any sort of graphical options or benchmarks.  Gameplay: Where do i begin. This game plays, as well as you can play it. All the mechanics are there for you to make it work in your favor. But finding your niche and finding your work space is all crucial in you enjoying your time in Terraria. The game drops you into a world, where you basically don't understand anything, A very limited spread of understanding, very few tools at your disposal, and a single NPC to help guide you along your journey. 4 classes to basically choose from as you progress through the game, Melee, Ranged, Mage and Summoner. All depending on how you want to play and how you prefer to play. Despite there being no relevant story or backstory to this game, there is a substantial amount of progression and ALOT of gear to rummage around for.  Story: I think i pretty much covered this aspect of the game already. There really isn't a story here. Which is usually a game killer for me. I heavily invest in story driven worlds, And this world has none to speak of. I guess the story can be made up for each player, as to why you are doing what you're doing, but as for a story driven narrative. There isn't one.  I don't often do a "CONS" section. But this game is so monstrous in terms of scope and size, I feel it's necessary to provide as much information as possible. I love this game to bits, this is perhaps the 3rd time i've played it through, Once on playstation, once on Xbox and now on PC. So i'm well aware of his rather frustrating flaws. So here we are.... Cons: This game despite how much effort has been poured into it, Has rather sizable and numerous flaws. Mostly relating around achievement glitches, game crashing and multiplayer bugs. Achievement glitches are fairly frustrating, although are entirely not a concern unless you're as OCD as i am. The game progresses the same way regardless of steams registering of your progress. Game crashes for alot of players at certain intervals in the game, Which HAS caused loss of character saves. It's highly recommended that you cloud save your favorite character builds and worlds, so that your save data will always be present. And Multiplayer as a whole is a fairly awful experience, the above mention bugs as well as an assortment of new things, Players not seeing what each other are seeing, Enemies and bosses despawning because of numerous players involved, which may or may not potentially ruin hours upon hours of preparation and planning. Frustrating to say the least. But alot of it is avoidable if you take necessary precautions. Alot of which can be found through quick internet searches.  Overall: This game is a gigantic time suck lol There is no other way to put it, You will pour time into boss by boss progression, farming and grinding enemies for specific gear to better improve your chances at the next boss. You will dig deep into dirt, mud and ash for hours upon hours just to find 3 pieces of ore which isn't even close to the amount you need. You will kill thousands of enemies for a single piece of gear, that isn't even optimal till you find another piece it can be fused with. You will die on the inside for days and potentially weeks as you farm your way to the very end of the game. And then when it's all over and you finally can get a breath of respite as your real life world is crumbling to pieces around you, You will feel empty, knowing that it's done. This game isn't just worth its price, It's worth every minute you pour into it. Welcome to Terraria. I hope you enjoy it as much as i do.

Review: This is probably one of the best Games here on Steam.  I first bought this Game back in 2013 and after dying a couple of times I didnt touch it for a while. However after playing it with a friend I discovered what a gem it really is.  Terraria is a 2D Adventure, Survival, Crafting Game that is just perfect in every way. It also is very optimised and recieved lots of updates making building (Thank you for the smart Cursor) & moving around the world (Thank you for the different mounts) alot easier.  Terraria is so Cheap but you can spend so much time on it. It basically is never ending fun and now with the achievements it will be easy ish to get 100%. The only grinding bit will be the fishing quests you'll need to do.  There is honestly so much to do and it is an absolut gem. You just have to try it out yourself and if you dont want to spend 10‚Ç¨ (which is already really cheap for this kind of game) then you can always wait for a sale and grab it there!  Now this Game might not have the best "graphics" but it is lovely the way it is and it shouldn't be in any other way.  I highly recommend this Game to any Minecraft, Metroidvania & 100% Achievement Fan. But even if you are not one of those, the Chances that you will dislike this Game are very low! So just give it a shot!

Review: As someone who's over 1800 hours in, I can tell you with confidence that this game is a MASTERPIECE. There are A LOT of things I could say about Terraria, but put quite simply: it's worth every penny.  The bosses are a blast, each class is fun in their own unique way, Expert difficulty is perfection (Normal is too easy and you get less loot; don't ever play on Normal), even the NPCs all have their uses! Technically speaking, an NPC is only ever useless depending on your class or personal preference (e.g. some people may not care for the Angler achievements, or a mage might not care for the Arms Dealer, etc.).  You will always have something to do, at pretty much any given point in the game. And even when you've 'beaten' the game and gotten bored of your world, you could just make a new character, new world, and have a totally new experience! Then, even if you get bored of that, you can download tModloader for FREE, and mod the game to your hearts' content!  It's affordable, can run on most hardware, and is, dare-I-say, the perfect gaming experience. I can't recommend this game enough.

Review: I've put lots of time into this game, even before I bought it on Steam. When I did finally get it on Steam, I purchased two copies: one for myself, and one for my wife. We played together, helping each other collect health and mana upgrades, equipment upgrades, and collecting the NPCs. She fought off slimes and zombies while I established gardens for mushrooms, trees, and plants for potion ingredients. We mined, we explored dungeons and caves, we fought bosses and discovered how to navigate Hell.  It's been an amazing time, and this game has been well worth the amount of money I've spent on it. I've gotten more hours of enjoyment out of it, both alone and with my wife, than I have with nearly every $60 AAA game. The music, the graphics, the controls, and the amount of stuff available to do just make it an easy recommendation for me.

Review: Yes, after you've done everything in Terraria it can't get kind of boring, but there's some kind of magic that brings me and my friends to play it every get on every year and play it again. I've played this on console ever since I was little waiting for the update on 1.3 and it came but by the time it did I had switched to PC for this game and so had my friends. Writing this now I'm quite far away from my old friends but I'll be beat if I ever said no to playing Terraria with them. Get some friends on this game and make some memories, you'll enjoy it. And for the older and experienced players, keep that magic that you have with your friends. Very few people have that- even if it's just for a game. But isn't that really what it's about? Spending time, riffing and coupling the day to have a 1-hour pixel adventure. PLEASE play this game with friends. I would hate to have to see people playing Terraria alone because it makes me sad that you can't enjoy it with pals. Maybe it should be a recipe for all video games really, I mean even the first few games were made for two people. Games like pong and others require two people. Don't think you're so alone, there's more people out there that like your hobby; trust me.

Review: I just recently broke 1000 hours on this game, so I feel obligated to review it (and I want to, too!).  You‚Äôd think that if I‚Äôve played something for a thousand hours, I must like it. And you‚Äôd be right. Terraria is‚Ä¶ the best game I have ever played. But first, I must give you a little history of myself.  So, Terraria is the first real desktop game I played. By real, I mean not on a web browser (I played lots of arras.io). Before Terraria, I played Minecraft on my iPad. But only creative mode. I really liked building in Minecraft. Anyways, I was at a friend‚Äôs house, and my friend understood that I didn‚Äôt play any video games, so they let me try this game on their computer. I had no idea how to play, but I still liked it. Then, when I got my laptop, they bought me this game. We started playing it together, the three of us (one other friend as well). We finished the game in Normal mode while basically knowing little about how the game worked. Hell, we didn‚Äôt even know about double jumps, dashes, or the Goblin Tinkerer. We didn‚Äôt know why Moon Lord (the last boss) seemed to not be taking any damage. (After, we realized that he summons things that heal him unless you killed them. Even if we had realized at the time, we weren‚Äôt doing enough damage to kill the clots in time, anyways. I died 30 times and healed with the nurse more than 40 times in the winning fight. The fight took 45 minutes with the three of us. In classic mode, boss health doesn‚Äôt even scale, so we should have killed it in 2 minutes, because the average kill time for one person is 6 minutes.) Sorry if you have no idea what I‚Äôm talking about.  After that first multiplayer playthrough, I spent all my time reading the wiki and watching all sorts of youtube videos. Not even playing, just reading and watching. I memorized all the important things about the game, and learned insane strategies. And then I found multiplayer servers.  I had no idea what servers were at the time. I followed a youtube video to join one. I was immediately overwhelmed. So confusing stuff. So, there‚Äôs this server software thing called TShock which is essentially a mod for servers. You can teleport people, give them items, butcher enemies, etc. All by typing in a command! (For those of you that play minecraft, think of the command console. Same idea.) I have the capacity to learn quickly, so I did. The server had all sorts of stuff. I became proficient at the minigames. As of this review, over 700 of my 1000 hours on the game are on that one server. I have tried other servers, but that one is the best, in my opinion. (IP: penguingames.fun Port: 7777)  The bad side of playing on servers is that you don‚Äôt improve much at the regular game. The minigames (such as Parkour) use weird techniques and stuff that you will never use in a normal playthrough. So, even after all these hours, I am very. Very. Bad. At the base game. But I know the theory and stats.  Okay, here‚Äôs the actual review. Gameplay 10/10. Decoration 8/10. Sprites 8/10. Animation 7/10. UI 8.5/10. Very balanced game overall. In classic/normal mode, if you pay enough attention, you will rarely die. In master mode (hardest mode), everything kills you in 2 or 3 hits, maybe 5 with endgame overpowered armor and stuff. Lots of unique items. Over 15 bosses to fight. Some bosses are bullet hell-type. 10 or so biomes to explore, plus unique structures. Enemies are interesting. Most major bugs have been fixed.  Lastly, let‚Äôs look at mods. These are player/fan-made additions to the game. Mods can be played using tModLoader, a game that you can get for free on steam if you own terraria. I‚Äôm not going to cover how to install them. Mods vary from overhauling the game, adding better sprites (wait, actually that‚Äôs a texture pack), quality of life, new bosses, new AI for enemies in the base game, to adding extra-large worlds and doubling the number of items. All that! Just for 10 dollars (5 while on sale).  I haven‚Äôt completed any singleplayer playthrough of this game (had other stuff to do), but I am working on defeating all bosses without taking damage. I have also played a few other games since I got this one, namely: DRG (deep rock galactic), Core Keeper, Geometry Dash, and Splitgate. Terraria is still the most fun‚Ä¶  TL,DR: great gameplay, feels smooth and semi-balanced (logic is weird though), lots of content, cheap for the price, endless possibilities. You can build amazing stuff. Overall rating 9.5/10. Get this game. Thanks for reading!  My youtube channel that I upload Terraria content on: (let's see if steam lets me post this link)

The planet sized playground that calls itself Terraria blows my little mind.

Review: As of writing this review I have invested 1038 hours into this game and I have been waiting for a good time to post a review and I think now is a good time. Terraria is a game were you explore craft and fight many exciting bosses. First up, I have found that the replayability is never a problem saying that I have had countless playthroughs and each one has never been quite the same. Terraria offers 4 different classes (Melee, Ranged, Magic and Summoner) to play as and each one has its own way to play. Terraria's progression is fantastic! You start with nothing but, once you kill your first boss you can start to feel that much deserved power spike. Terraria's progression is filled with 17 bosses that give the player new items and unlocks new tiers of loot and harder bosses. Some of the games core bosses are not necessary to fight in order to move on with the game which is a nice addition. Terraria's events are completely optional but they offer new and strong weapons, armor and accessories to spice things up. Terraria can be played with your friends also which just adds to the amount of fun that you can have when playing. If you ever get bored of the content that is in the game, Terraria offers official mod support! that gives a countless selection of mods to play around with. Terraria also has it's own official Wiki page that can give you information on any aspect of the game and it's mechanics. Final Thought: I bought Terraria back when it was 20$ and looking back on that purchase I regret nothing. I have found myself coming back to this game over and over again over the years. This game is an absolute GEM of a game and for 10$ it's such a steal!

Review: Today Terraria and I, we have our anniversary, ten years together! More than 1700 hours of great fun and memorable moments, most of this I played solo but there were times when I shared my adventures with friends (although its about 500 hours while 1200 solo). Terraria is a great game and one of the greatest ever made, not only because of this constant labours of love but also because the great gameplay loop, graphics, music and atmosphere. While I don't have the most hours and I am definitely not the best player, this game to this day gives me the best enjoyment (and also best tediousness). The thing I like the most about it (probably) is the connection that was established between gamers and Terraria (well, mostly its developer Re-Logic). Taking input, talking to fans, giving them updates (even If they want them or not) and being quite nice towards other developers (reminder of their contribution to GODOT engine). That the feel of community between creator&recipient helped the game for such a long stay on top with positive reviews and positive attitude towards it.  However all good things must come to the end. What will happen when that last update will come (maybe it will never)? Will there be another project, studio, return to updates after promising no more or simply T2? Will it surpass the original or maybe will bring something completely new? I trust Re-Logic, they earned it, there will be something great in the future, May the expectations/fans not kill anything new, other than Terraria.  Terraria is one of those games that happens once in a lifetime, I am glad it was part of my life for the last 10 years! May the next 10 years also bring the great time!  Ps1 I also have one unfulfilled dream with Terraria, that maybe will come with help of the modders. For the longest of time there was one Corruption and one Hallow, later came Crimson to paint the world red. I really would like to see another late game Holy/Good, alternate Hallow.

Review: (it contain small spoilers what is ahead, skip this story if you just want to witness yourself and go directly to quick review section. Also I kinda had to update this review a little bit, minor fixing on my writing and maybe adding some more stuff for my story part.)  Terraria...  It's been over 9 years since it has been released on steam and perhaps still over 9 years since I got my hands on this pure gem.  When I first time saw this as pretty foolish person and thinking this being just "2D Minecraft" but thankfully I was completely wrong about it and getting really into this game.  Sure your first time playing this game might be so slow and boring, but once you get your hands on very interesting gears and meet very important people that sells even much more interesting stuff, then this game slowly starting to get some speed, also don't forget to build houses for them.  The first time when I was capable enough to take on the Wall of Flesh, I was very certain this was the final boss of the game, until for the surprise it unlocked the hardmode and I reacted by saying: "I'm sorry what?"  Upon that moment I realized the adventure was just getting started, but eventually I was getting bored with the game even couple years later when I played with group of friends, it didn't take long until we decided to stop playing. Although I did enjoy the fun time in the game and I will never forget that time when I tricked someone to step on the pressure plate that was rigged with explosives.  Few years later I decided to check back in the game and wow how much it has been changed from and started to play again to see what new and exciting things to discover and this time I did play little bit longer.  On this time I felt it gave more content than enough for me to at least write down the review, but oddly enough it felt like it was missing something from all this so I decided not to make the review.  Upon this year near spring time, they announced upcoming perhaps truly final update for the game: "Journey's End"  That update was a huge one when it arrived and I personally felt like it is finally time to finally finish this game on hardest possible difficulty, so I finally created my final character, my final world, readying my copper blade and getting almost instantly killed by green slime!  Yes...  it is that hard, but I decided to keep going even if it was going to drive me completely insane because of it, until on that moment when I soldiered on this pure madness, I finally was face to face with the official final boss of Terraria... The Moon Lord and boy how much tries it took until I was near only 3 HP left on my character before finally defeating it and it never felt so good when I saw it dying and seeing the credit rolling for the first time.  But...  Now I feel this adventure isn't just over yet, especially when they added new content and I now have a urge to conquer the master mode and something else from beyond.  Now for the actual review.   Goods  +Gameplay Gameplay of the game is very simple at first, but it steadily get harder when you find new tools, weapons and trinkets that give you new way to play the game and there are basically "classes" on the game, for example: warrior, summoner, archer/gunner and mage, there are more "classes" but you can make your own "class" by mixing up the armor, trinkets and others giving you chance to experiment every items what you find and what mostly suit your style.  +Art style The art style of the game is really pretty and all these years the art style has been improved quite a lot and especially the background since every area change the scenery and certain event affect the scenery as well, there are also lots of small details to see and some few changes on clouds as well.  +Music The music of this game is pure classic and all of them did have the tunes improved little bit and few news has been added after the journey's end update, there is also now otherworld version of ost that you can change it in the game after finding the certain secret.  +Price It's literally 10‚Ç¨ for several hours of fun and especially with friends.   Decents  =playtime You can easily sink great amount of time on either playing the game to end, crafting your perfect world or anything else, although if you just made completely new character and new world, the playtime might take quite a time until you get on the speed.  =Loot drop chance It might be little bit annoying to try getting the certain items from certain enemy, but there are few ways to make it easier.   Bads  -bugs/crashing I can't think of anything else being bad than bugged game or game crashing out of nowhere, but these are so rare you could just say: "what bugs?"   Conclusion This game is pure classic since it was almost 10 years of it release on steam and this "final" update really show how much RE-Logic care about this game and it's fans, not only you get this great game pretty cheap, you also get lots of fun to explore the world, fighting powerful enemies, finding awesome treasures, build your own world and last but most importantly making your own story on this game on yourself or with your friends.  Welp, that's all for now.  Doktor Greenman, logging out.

Review: I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Terraria. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories. Thank you <3

Review: After all these years I can tell Terraria is one of the best, well done and most entertaining games of its kind out here! I still remember the days when killing skeletron was considered endgame, good days. The devs've made an insane progress since then and only for the best - I couldn't imagine Terraria would turn into such content rich and entertaining sandbox.  Why do I reccomend it? That's why: - Fast paced, stylish (even though very simple) combat - Attractive pixel graphics - Well done character/world progression - Beautiful environment - A lot to explore, every playthrough is somewhat different - Great soundtrack - You can build! And it actually has a purpose! - Every boss is forever in my heart<3 - Customize character looks (very important for me) - Even better with friends - And the last, but not the least - the game doesn't require a NASA computer to play it  10 slimes out of 10 slimes! Will definitely play it again, over and over...

Review: The Journey Has Ended, and What A Ride  Terraria is a video game. You can play it. I hope this information does not startle you. It's a 2D game that, at first blush, evokes Minecraft - It's open world, it's got base building, it's got monster slaughter by the gallons, it's got fishing, good lord has it got fishing, it's got potion-making, it's got a lot of something for everybody.  Your first mistake is in assuming it's just 2D Minecraft. It's not. It's a bit more linear, for one thing; Your progression is a little nebulous, but it begins with digging. You can dig up ores and craft stuff, so you do this for a while, slowly getting stronger and stronger. Then you discover that, no, Terraria has plans for you. Your nights might begin peacefully, calm even, but this is a lull before the game punches you in the stomach with your first boss fight.  Thankfully for your sanity, the game does offer several means of making this progression less of a guessing game. You have an NPC guide who can tell you what your next few moves should be, from getting stronger, to what boss fights you'll need to do next, to just offering miscellaneous tips and suggestions. In fact, your towns are a priority. You'll attract more and more NPCs as the game goes on, each offering services for coins you'll collect while slaughtering monsters. From items, to healing on the cheap, to modifying items, NPCs will cover a wide array of useful things, so it's always worth having them around, but to have them, you'll need houses.  You keep this loop going, and eventually the game opens up more and more as you get further along. So on, and so forth.  There's something for everyone. If you want to go into combat with melee, archery, guns, summoning minions, or wielding magic, the game accommodates all these styles, giving them their own strengths and drawbacks. If you want to build, the game offers you a lot of options for materials, paints, making buildings look nice, and as the game goes on, you'll be able to dabble in engineering. This said, having a combat 'class' is a must, as you'll need to fight to make progress.  In short, Terraria offers everyone, of all playstyles, a way to enjoy themselves.  The story is there, on the website, but it also doesn't really matter at all. It's certainly worth looking up if you're really invested into Terraria, but it's not going to affect gameplay at all, so there's no need to bother.  Graphically, Terraria... Really does resemble Minecraft in two dimensions. It's pixelated art can vary from cheery and colorful to eldritch or disgusting on a dime, a cheerful facade hiding grim undertones. It's also very easy on the eyes as a whole, so that's a plus, and it can cover and convey a variety of themes, locales, enemies, and bosses without anything feeling dissonant from where it's supposed to be as a result.  In terms of sounds, Terraria's music can, again, range from cheerfully peppy to hopelessly bleak at a moment's notice, and in a lot of cases can do so with absolute whiplash between normal and , and enemy sound effects cover a melange of themes and sounds, from the light of the Hallow, to the suitably spooky 'evil' biomes, to the underground desert's dryer tones. It all never feels too out of place, but it can grate a little given time.  Performance-wise, I admit to wielding an overkill PC, but the game never stutters or falters, even on older hardware - For as deep as Terraria is, it's remarkably lightweight and easy to run.  Multiplayer is a key selling point of Terraria. There's a 4-pack of copies you can buy so you can give three more buddies the game, and it's undeniably far better with friends then solo. Not only is it more people, but having a friend to laugh over luck with or share in the glory is always a good thing in my book, and on that front, Terraria more then delivers, both in co-operative play and competition via PvP.  I don't have many gripes with Terraria. Some of it's systems can be frustrating, and the RNG reliance hurts somewhat, but it hasn't stopped me from enjoying all my time spent with the game. Still, for some players, the game's progression can be a bit too vague and frustrating, trying to find where to go can be an exercise in patience sometimes, and when the RNG decides to screw you over, it really does not hold back on that front.  Even then, it's a fun time, and at only ten dollars, it's very much worth the base asking price. If you've ever wanted to know what Minecraft could do if it was a little less open-ended, Terraria is a worthwhile time, especially with buddies.

Review: Product received for free  Holy hell. What a ride this has been.  I first recieved this game when I was selected as the winner of a giveaway. I thought, "Whatever, I've played Minecraft. This game is probably the exact same as it." After all, there are certain similarities between both games. Find yourself stranded in the wilderness, mine ores and create some bland weapons and kill a generic boss and win.  But the similarities end exactly there.  Now, this game, in the starting phase, is actually quite bland, and I nearly quit because of it at first, but with the help of some friends, I stuck with it. It was pretty generic stuff. Mine some boring ores, build a boring house, feel the occasional rush of excitement of succesfully spelunking a cave and escaping unscathed with a new weapon, or dying and dropping your money. You'll die quite a bit as well, but don't let that discourage you. The moment I realized the exact depth of the game (and realized Iactually loved this game) was the moment my friends and I summoned what is to be considered the first boss, the Eye of Cthulu. The intensity of the battle, especially with our underprepared selves and crappy armor (hint: armor is your best friend!) made victory all the more satisfying. The adrenaline rushes as a boss attack leaves you at low health and your struggle to survive easily surpasses Minecraft in it's entertainment value. Yet I believed that was all the game had to offer, that one bit of awesomeness.  WRONG!  Excluding event bosses, there are over 14 different and unique bosses of Terraria, each with their own unique powers, and in Expert mode, their strength is vastly increased and each boss gains a lethal special attack, from the Eye of Cthulu's blinding fast rushes to the Skeletron's deadly skull spin. No two bosses are the same, nor can they be approached in the same way. Nearly every boss requires meticulous planning and building. But that's not all. because you know what's better than killing a boss?  Sweet, sweet loot.  Emerging victorious from a boss fight is definitely cause for celebration, but emerging victorious with a new weapon is even better. From shields that allow for bash-like charging, to a scarf that reduces damage by 17%, every boss kill is new and gratifying with the loot.  Now, about now is where you can pick your specialization, especially if you're playing with friends. Will you be the hulking tank, absorbing all of the damage to protect your teammates? Or the looming mage, casting deadly spells from behind, or an archer, raining down death from above? It doesn't matter. After all, in Terraria, you're free to do what you want.  And right when you think things are getting bland again, hardmode hits you. All of your weapons and armor's effectiveness is quartered. Enemies are a challenge again. Venturing out at night is a near death sentence. New enemies will spawn, and new loot along with it. But again, don't be discouraged. You'll die quite a bit, after all. Build your strength up again, and go kick some ass.

Review: When I first jumped in, I went for a walk, got overwhelmed by slimes. Dead. After I respawned, I went for another walk and found a cave. A slime pushed off a huuuge dropoff. Dead. Built a quick simple shelter to survive the zombie horde at night, forgot to build doors. Dead. Started mining down the next morning, Swarmed by cave bats. Dead. Kept digging until I fell into lava in the underworld. Dead. Tried again but this time I killed a flying demon! (He dropped a doll into the lava and spawned a boss.) Dead. Became a decent enough player who could survive on mastermode, tried the boss again. Dead. Upgraded my base, got better weapons and armor, went back to the Unde-- Dead. I the- Dead. -- Dead.

Review: This is literally God's gift to video games. You can have over 1,000 hours in this game and still be surprised. The amount of content is frankly ASTOUNDING. The complexity, depth, and sheer magnitude of this game blows my mind every time I play it. There isn't a story, but there is clearly lore to uncover. You'll mostly be mining, fighting, building, and testing your creativity with different combinations of weapons and movement systems. There are many different types of armor which allow you to move in many different ways, which allows you to enhance your combat abilities against different enemies and just traverse the land / explore more easily. There are 83 different wearable movement items, to be exact....  Just kidding, that's JUST THE NUMBER OF DIFFERENT WINGS. AND WINGS AREN'T EVEN THE ONLY ITEMS THAT ENABLE YOU TO FLY.  There's rocket boots, hoverboards, rideable animals, space ships... Magical staffs, bows, swords, axes, rifles, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• machine guns, etc. The list of movement & combat items goes on forever, There are SO many different enemies, interesting bosses, and ways to fight them. The ONLY people in the world who won't enjoy this game are people who don't enjoy mining/exploring, or people who just hate platformers regardless of how good they are. If you're not one of those people, buy this game.  I was confused when I first played, so here's my TLDR run-down of the game if you don't understand what the goal is (Assuming you're starting in a new world with a fresh character): Start with a few basic tools, build yourself a house (preferably multiple houses) which, once certain requirements are met, NPCs will move into. These NPCs will offer you different benefits and sell you interesting items, some of which are exclusive to them. The bosses in the world can either be summoned with different items, or will spawn in front of you once certain requirements are met. You want to beat the bosses for mainly 2 reasons: They drop amazing items, and/or they allow you to get certain new NPCs to move into your house. For example, defeating the Queen Bee will cause the Witch Doctor NPC to move into your house, who will sell you a great pair of Wings when you put him in a Jungle biome at night (yes, the Wiki is your best friend). So the goal of the game is to keep getting better metals/materials to make yourself better weapons/armor so you can beat stronger enemies/bosses so you can keep getting better metals/materials and so on. Once you beat the Wall of Flesh boss (which you have to summon in the Underworld by throwing a Voodoo Doll into a pit of lava), your entire world - including most enemies and metal ores - will change to Hardmode, and you'll pretty much feel like you're starting over again because enemies will once again be able to kick your ass and more bosses will become available to fight and more items will become available to craft.  That's just the surface level of the game, but that's the best general explanation I can give for people who are still like "wtf is this game, what is my goal, what do I do" because that's how I felt when I first played.  If you want a great explanation of why I love this game in video format, check out "Terraria - Best video game ever made" on YouTube by Maj0rLee. I'm not affiliated with him, it's just a great video about the game if you're still on the fence.   P.S. If you think this game looks appealing to you but you're more interested in a more linear, story-driven experience, check out Starbound. It's also really good, and is similar in its scope/style.

Review: After finally attaining the last achievement for Terraria I can say that I feel almost prepared to write a meh review.  Terraria on the surface level seems pretty simple.. right? A charming pixel game with linear-ish progression and an open world sandbox... is what I would say if it weren't for the crafting in this game. The game doesn't slack off when it comes to crafting so if you haven't purchased a second monitor to play Terraria on than go and buy one, it's kind of essential due to the fact you will have the wiki open 99% of the time.  Terraria features items in the thousands and everything will craft into something else eventually, the amount of stuff the dev's have put into their small little indie game is simply insane and should keep you busy for a few hours ;). The bosses in Terraria are all beautifully designed and actually manage to have a thread of lore linking them together, which is surprising for a sandbox game like Terraria. Once you are done with the bosses though there is literally unlimited possibilities for expanding and designing your world, with the addition of Journey mode this becomes even easier aswell.  Lastly before the review ends I thought it might be prudent to mention the fact that Terraria has kept its price near-consistent the entire time that it's been released with a slight price bump towards it's final update. Regardless of this, the amount of content you get for the price is simply tremendous and this is coupled with the fact that Terraria is almost always on some sort of sale, there's no reason to not have it really.

Review: Huge amount of content, procedurally generated worlds, quite a few choices in playstyles for characters in the late game when you get kit that provides specific bonuses to damage types, lots of bosses, lots of mobs, lots of buffs/debuffs, quite a few techniques to master, a good feel of progression across hours of play, active development (after a long hiatus in the middle), and a good community. Building/crafting is intuitive and fast albeit 2d, and the game makes for a very fun co-op experience if you have friends to play with.  At its price bracket, the value for time spent is phenomenal if you like the idea of a 2d sandbox platformer with boss fights and the excitement of the next loot drop. Difficulty scales nicely (and has an "expert" mode for those that find the default game a bit easy), World size is variable, and the penalty on dying can be chosen from "drop some money and nothing else" to "your character is dead, please start again".  One of the nicest features of Terraria is the ability to have characters and worlds that aren't tied to each other. So if you're looking for a specific item that doesn't seem to be on your world, you can just generate a new one, take your character there to farm for items, and then go back to your main world - or you can start a brand new character on a world you've already built up with NPCs and everything else rather than needing to completely start from scratch each time - not many games have managed to pull this off so well.  The game is also very kid friendly, and has been a fun family multiplayer game in this house many times over.  Summary  Excellent 2D platformer with crafting, boss fights, huge amounts of content from aesthetics to rare items and godly weapons, the ability to continually improve your character over hours of play, and well designed procedurally generated levels. Great single player experience, great multiplayer experience as long as you have other friends or family members to play with. Very cheap for the amount of content and game there is available.

Review: Product received for free  Terraria is the best game in its genre. Don't believe me? Now I will PROVE it to you. 1. You become more reserved and patient. After all, when you lose to Moonlord for the tenth time, you really want to drill a hole in the monitor, don‚Äôt you? However, after a couple of worlds in the master mode, you begin to understand reality and accept this harsh life as it is. 2. You begin to better navigate Wikipedia, because remembering recipes for more than FIVE THOUSAND is not so easy, right? But in addition to items, you will have to look for how to summon bosses, how to kill them, how to move NPCs into your home, how to buy the pylon you need, how to repay a loan, how to get a girlfriend, how to support your family with your last cents.... oh, That's not what I was talking about. 3. You don't need a high resolution monitor. Pixel games are cool. 4. Do you really need any more reasons to download this masterpiece game?  I'll be honest, for the first ten hours of the game you will be plagued by paranoia and increased temper. It will pass soon, don't worry. After the rehabilitation period in a mental hospital, you will feel that same feeling of peace and tranquility.  10/10 Broken Zeniths  P. S. I hope the translator translated this text correctly.

Review: Probably best 2D sandbox ever made. The amount of items you can craft or get and enemies you can defeat (including bosses) is just sometimes overwhelming.  The game has 2 stages :  1) Pre-hardmode - basically a longer "tutorial" where you learn basics such as crafting, fighting monsters and exploring biomes, this stage ends when you kill certain boss in the underground called wall of flesh.  2) Hardmode - the real game begins here, monsters are stronger and new biomes appear, a lot of game content unlocks only in this mode. This stage remains forever (or you can count defeating the last boss as a end of it).  There are a lot of decorative items and furniture so builders won't be dissapointed though I was focused more on exploring and fighting rather than building.  Highly recommend this game but be careful - its addictive :)

Review: Overall : 9/10 A friend recommended this game, but I was hesitant to buy it at first. It looked like a minecraft ripoff in a 2D world. The large amount of positive reviews and the low prive (4.99 euro at that time) convinced me to give this a try.  I could not have been more wrong. This game is awesome ! The amount of content, the freedom, the difficulty level, the items and achievements you can collect, all of this make it one of the best games I have ever played.  You can: 1 Create large buildings 2 Collect loads of items, weapons and armor 3 Explore a huge map 4 Become a badass warrior and defeat enormous bosses 5 ...  One thing I really like is what changes if you play on the highest difficulty level. Ofcours everything gets a lot harder, but you are also able to get better and more drops (items) from enemies. This feels like the game is rewarding you for playing on a higher difficulty.  There is even a multiplayer aspect, which makes it even better. It is really fun to play with friends.  Graphics : 8/10 Not too impressive, a 2D world map. The graphics itself are outdated but create the perfect atmosphere for this game. You can create 2 types of worlds, which each have a different dark environment. Multiple biomes (forest, jungle, desert, ...) exist, with its own unique enemies and environment.  Optimization : 9/10 Good optimization, 60 fps on 1440p-max on a gtx 980 (overclocked) with v-sync on. Without v-sync, the fps went up to a stable 165 fps, but for some reason playing on 60 fps is more enjoyable.  Story : 2/10 This is where the game is lacking at the moment. Actually no story exists, you are free to create your own :)  Length : 10/10 I killed the final boss after 125 hours on the highest difficulty. This is awesome for a game where I payed 4.99 for. The game is not finished though. I can still perfect my house, kill other bosses, collect items, explore some more...  I have around 180 games in my steam library, after 2 weeks this game is in the top 3 of most played games. Enough said.  Replayablity : 10/10 Each world you create, is unique because they are created based upon a "seed". As stated above, each world has its unique dark environment. The type is selected upon world creation. There are different type of ores, but each world will only contain . This means each world will play differently and you need to create a lot of worlds to be able to collect all the items in the game.  Because of this you will never be able to see al the content and achievements on your first playthrough.  Update : They are still updating the game :)

Review: AT A GLANCE (Full review follows below)  Game Name: Terraria Original Release: 2011 Genre Tags: Open-world; 2D; Sandbox; Survival; Multiplayer My Overall Grade: A+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): N/A Multiplayer Aspect: Optional Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers; Sandbox players; Casual gamers; Multiplayer gamers  REVIEW is already a well-known game. There probably isn‚Äôt much I can say which hasn‚Äôt already been said. Many gamers have heard of it, and many gamers know it is considered to be generally ‚Äúgreat,‚Äù transcending most genre preferences and prejudices. And I now count myself among those people. But the inherent quality of isn‚Äôt necessarily that obvious when a total newcomer decides to give it a shot, as the game can be quite uninviting at first. And that is something I want to address.  So I will tell you, like the thousands of others, that is an incredibly enjoyable game. It is hard to concisely describe exactly it is so enjoyable; but it basically boils down to the fact that there is an air of quality inherent to every gameplay aspect and those aspects synergize so well that that quality is multiplied exponentially in the end result.  But when I first decided to try it, I failed three times to get into it. Each time I sat down and tried to see what all the fuss was about, but each time I wound up extremely bored and confused as to why I couldn‚Äôt see what was supposed to be so fun about it. The lack of any clear purpose and direction at the start of the game had me running around with no real incentives, and it ended up feeling unrewarding. Then I played with some new friends online who could offer a bit of direction. We started a new world together and the next thing I knew hours had flown by and I realized that I was finally enlightened.  It was difficult to get over the initial hump of a learning curve and having a starter character. There is no tutorial, there are no objectives; simply moving around is tedious at first, the digging is slow, and the building options are minimal‚Ä¶ and it can all feel rather boring. But when you finally start making progress into the game, all the upgrades and item-tiers you climb through feel so gratifying. And I think having that initial slow-climbing grind at the start is a major part of what makes the game so satisfying once you finally delve into the heart of it.  Once you reach this point of enlightenment, you will be eager to explore all that has to offer. Hunt down exotic loot. Fight epic boss battles. Build giant castles with thousands of items. Make new friends and enjoy the enormous replayability of playing online. Maybe even try a role-play server. There are many hours of fun to be had.  Perhaps the only negative aspects worth noting are the simplistic graphics and the lack of any clear story-mode. But due to the great gameplay and nature of the game, both of these things are easily dismissed as a non-issue by most. That said, if you really like story-driven experiences and/or gorgeous, current-gen graphics, you definitely won‚Äôt find those here.  So in short, is something that can be easily enjoyed by almost any gamer. If you haven‚Äôt yet given it a go, you should probably consider it. It is a pretty safe bet for all but the most extremely discerning gamers. Just don‚Äôt forget that it may feel boring at first, but it is worth fighting past it; and playing with some people online can make it significantly more fun, especially when you are new.
