Review: Well I think it's about time to review this gem.  Terraria is one of the best value-per-dollar games you can buy on steam. Period. Obviously some of the free-to-play games can match that value (because you spend nothing) but the amount of content in this game is just ridiculous!  Ever since 1.0, there have been 3 absolutely game-changing updates, for completely free. The game was already worth it just at 1.0, apart from bugs, but then they litterally quadrupuled or quintupled every aspect of the game. 1.0 got the basics right; satisfying combat, fun exploration, lots of sandboxy things to do, but as I just said, it's sandboxy; there's a lack of an appropriate ending besides "get the most powerful stuff." 1.3 gave us the Moon Lord which is the equivilant of the Ender Dragon from Minecraft; it doesn't end your game after you defeat it but it's something tough even with the gear you get from him, so it feels like a climactic end.  You'll start off small with your copper shortsword, or maybe you build the wooden broadsword to replace it. After many hours you'll have slowly went through the arsenal of weapons and armor the game provides you, from bows to guns to MAGIC, and from simple "take less damage" armor to armor that has really unique effects such as allowing you to reflect damage and draw aggro from enemies for your friends.  On top of the weaponry you have all of the things to do with blockbuilding. There's so many pieces of furnature and different materials you can use to make something that looks amazing, and then you can customize it further by changing shapes with a hammer or recoloring blocks through the paint gun. On top of those cosmetic things you also have the (as of a recent update) fairly extensive wiring system that can allow you to create some pretty cool traps or other mechanisms such as spawning enemies or opening/closing doors.  And on top of THAT you have the massive variety of enemies to fight, some of which will completely obliterate you and you'll enjoy every minute of it. All of the bosses have their unique elements and you'll definitely be surprised the first time a signature move comes out (like the first time that the Corruption boss comes out of the ground).  AND ON TOP OF THAT you have a thriving modding community if the base game doesn't have enough content. Whether you just want more content or complete overhauls, the modding community's got you covered in user-friendly mod managers and easy mod installation.  So basically I'm saying the game's pretty good and you should buy it if you haven't already with how often it goes on 50% and 75% sales.  EDIT: Also you guys should totally nominate this game for the "Test of Time" reward because the game has always been great and it just keeps getting better and it's one of those games that pretty much every person on Steam has enjoyed at one point and returned to it at another when updates come out.

Review: Ohhhhh my god where do I start with this game? I bought this game when I was first getting into Steam and believe me, I have never spent ten bucks better. There is so much to do in this game that make this so-called "Minecraft clone" unique and rewarding.  Here's what makes Terraria so engaging:  -5 bosses before it even gets "hard," took me about 30 hours -gameplay is never repetitive or frustratingly difficult -awe-inspiring ores and treasures that puts Minecraft diamond to shame -the moment you find something new and you can't get over how great it is, you'll find something better (you'll see what I mean) -fast-paced game progression -80+ hours in one game and I haven't beaten it yet -surprisingly intricate building (just google Terraria builds)  Just a few things to keep in mind if you're a completely new player:  -there's no tutorial, so prepare to bookmark the Terraria wiki -it's way more fun to play co-op -the first few hours are admittedly slow, but the game just gets better the longer you play -yes, there is fall damage  Do yourself a favor and get this game.  Eat. Sleep. Terraria.

Review: Ok, here goes my belated review:  Man, I wish the final major update (1.4) came out earlier... or maybe wish I started playing this game when 1.4 came out... I don't know...  I have 500+ hours of playtime in this game, and had... great fun. Don't get me wrong, it's still a fun game, and the final major update is simply amazing... but, I've already done so many things within my playtime, such as building a nice base for my NPCs, defeating bosses (including Dungeon Guardian), defeating events, beating expert difficulty, building teleport spots, hellevators, traps, arenas, fishing spots in every biome, getting or crafting all weapons, getting all banners, etc, etc, you name it. I'm pretty sure many others like me are in the same boat. But I feel like I'm burnt out. I don't know, maybe the game ended for me after that final boss in 1.3...  Now, the game still is an amazing experience full of possibilities if you like building stuff using your creativity. The latest update adds a lot to that, as well. We also have mod tools now, which is awesome. I think (well, I hope) I'll be back one day to start a new game and build stuff once again. I can already see myself trying new stuff, but, I just can't bring myself back to it.  To put it simply, Terraria is a game that keeps on giving. Wholeheartedly recommended.

Review: Terraria is a game that has stood the test of time and continues to captivate players with its unique blend of exploration, combat, and creativity. This 2D sandbox game has been a favorite among gamers since its initial release in 2011, and it's easy to see why.  The game offers a vast and dynamic world to explore, filled with a variety of biomes, enemies, and treasures to discover. From the underground depths of the earth to the heights of the sky, there's always something new and exciting to uncover.  But Terraria isn't just about exploring - it also offers a robust combat system that will challenge even the most seasoned players. With an array of weapons, armor, and accessories to choose from, players can tailor their playstyle to suit their preferences and take on the game's bosses with confidence.  And let's not forget about the game's creative potential. With a plethora of building materials and tools at your disposal, you can let your imagination run wild and create everything from towering castles to intricate pixel art. The possibilities are endless, and the satisfaction of seeing your creations come to life is truly rewarding.  But what sets Terraria apart from other games in its genre is the sense of community it fosters. Whether you're playing with friends or joining a public server, the game encourages collaboration and creativity. From building massive structures together to taking on the game's challenges as a team, Terraria is a game that brings people together.  In conclusion, Terraria is a game that has something for everyone. Its vast world, engaging combat, and creative potential make it a must-play for any fan of sandbox games. But it's the sense of community that really sets it apart and makes it a game that will continue to be enjoyed for years to come.

Review: It'S 2-d MInecRaFt... said some boring chumps who refuse to play because of its similarities, while ignoring Fortnite's similarities to PubG. This game is more than 2-D Minecraft in its different styles, great 8bit music, affectionate pixel art and all- round attention, so much so that I believe it to be superior to Minecraft. It's not MC is bad, but just has some downsides... [HUGE TEXT FROM BLABBERING GUY AHEAD] __Comparing Terraria to Minecraft__ 1. Minecraft has a (in my opinion) weird progression structure- you mine underground until you find diamonds, game over- and makes the Nether and End feel only optional. The boss in MC doesn't really give you anything other than a decoration item and loads of empty islands, with one that gives you wings and some stuff. That makes it feel like a half-done ending. Meanwhile, Terraria has a better progression structure, involving killing bosses and getting gradually stronger until you beat the Moon Lord. That feels like a true ending, but really this is just a nitpick on MC. Sorry! 2. Minecraft has a limited amount you can do with it, which made me tire of it eventually. This is probably due to there being only 8 weapons and 5 armours, which restricts how many ways you can play. In Terraria, however, there are lots of weapons, armours and accessories and different classes to play as. This keeps the game fun since there are so many different ways to go through it, plus free and amazing mods too. (BTW I know Minecraft has mods, but I'm not sure many can contend with the huge, incredible, enchanting Calamity Mod which is basically a game on its own. Still, MC's mods are good.) 3. The most controversial one... Minecraft hasn't really got as much detail put into it. for example, biomes: Biomes in MC just means different blocks and a few new enemies that drop basic stuff. In Terraria, there's more detail put into those biomes, like loads of unique items, unique music and lots of biome-specific enemies. Although, MC does have a lot more detail in its oceans and does put effort into the Nether, so it isn't all bad. 4. THE WANDERING TRADER!! This I just can't forgive. The Wandering Trader is an obvious copy of the Travelling Merchant, but with nothing good that it had. Why, instead of getting 5 times more off the ground right where you live which regrow every two days, pay 6 emeralds for ONE FLOWER!? All he sells are weeds and junk, which is a big step down from the Travelling Merchant's good weapons, useful informative items and helpful food. The Wandering Trader just pops up around your house, doing all he can for him and his llama to make as much noise as possible to drive you insane. Then, as you look around to find him and shut him up, he drinks an invisibility potion and/or spawns in the greatest hiding spot in the area. The worst thing is that he has no use other than being annoying, and the only things I find him useful for is archery practice and eviscerating him to keep his nice-looking llama. Sorry about the wordy text and if it seems like I'm hating on MC, it's a good game. It's just I hate people who take one look at good games like Terraria and hate them for appearing like something else. I also took the opportunity to compare the games (sorry if it seems one-sided, I just love Terraria so much because both are so good, but could be so much better if they looked at each other more often and improved their games (EXCLUDING THE WANDERING TRADER, MINECRAFT SHOULD NOT HAVE "IMPROVED" ITSELF THEN). In brief, Terraria is a well-made sandbox RPG with flaws and potential, and not a Minecraft clone. Edit:So... my opinion changed a little after my opinion. People will ask why I don't post a bad review on Minecraft, and the answer is I don't want to directly give a bad review on a game that has potential, and I don't HATE.I don't necessarily despise MC, so take it easy when you read this. Also there will be loads of 8-year-olds screaming at me about an opinion that isn't part of their collective minds' blind following of the game played by their favourite (i.e the most unbearable they can find) Youtuber, and I don't want to cause a huge argument so I'm ranting where most won't look. Sorry for all the words...  After writing I played Minecraft again and I'm SHOCKED what's happened to it. It feels a lot more soulless than when I first played it, all the new stuff that they added seems exciting but was just... disappointing. I found an ocean monument, which looked cool, but only contained gold and some new blocks, so it was of no use and was just a disappointment. I raided a pillager outpost, I really wanted to know what was inside, but it was just generic chest loot and one new weapon that doesn't stand out much- a bigger disappointment. I then gave up on Survival after realising that there wasn't really much point to it anymore . I spent three sessions playing Survival, it just felt so abandoned, like it was just there because it was there originally. Call me petty, but that really made me like the game less.  Then, I played Creative mode, trying to build something, since blocks were almost the only thing being added (I said ALMOST, don't hurt me) and tried to build a house. This is where I reach something else I now dislike about the game...  REDSTONE SORTA SUCKS. It's over-complicated, the commands are fiddly and annoying, and I had to watch 6 TUTORIALS to make an item open a door! I know there are redstone masters out there, but it pains me as I wonder how long, how many excruciating hours it takes to get quite good at it. It's one of those cases where if they just took a page out of Terraria's book it would have massively improved the game. Think about it! Terraria's engineering system is pretty much a simple, easy concept to understand, but can do everything that Minecraft can. The wiring in Terraria doesn't eat up the odd 30x5x2 block space underneath your build, limiting what you can do. It doesn't need to have circuits that break if you place wires in a 2 by 2 space (redstone goes into a circle when you do that and stops working. It's simple, and can do so much!  I know I'm going to be bullied for adding this, people were already telling me how wrong I was to convey my opinion, but I really think replaying Minecraft has made it considerably less enjoyable to me. It's why I enjoy Terraria more, I'm only 12, I don't want to spend hours placing blocks or putting down wiring that usually doesn't work. I want a game that I can have fun with, not feel annoyed with and go round in circles. I don't hate Minecraft, but I think after Notch left, the game just lost its charm for me. One of the things I hate the most besides THAT TRADER is how the game just churns out updates every six months and shows no sign of stopping. My personal opinion is that Microsoft don't really care about the game they bought, they just keep updating it because "it's Minecraft" and people will buy it, and create low-effort updates to make sure that the 8-year-olds' attention spans don't run out and move on by adding a dribble of content, and give obnoxious Youtubers something to yell about and do let'splays on, dragging more 8-year-olds into Minecraft (sorry for the cliche view on that). At least the Terraria devs have decided to step away and finish with game-changing, good content, they didn't feel the need to keep it alive forever, milk it and stop caring about it other than for a paycheck.  Now, I do definitely prefer the chill, not-advertised-everywhere-with-merchandise-of-everything adventure of Terraria (I know they have merch too, but it's not too much and relatively hard to find), but I haven't given up hope on Minecraft yet. It may not be half of what it used to be, but I believe that there's still a chance that the game's production falls into the hands of a real fan, someone who will pull Minecraft back onto its feet, someone who puts the care and love into the game like Notch did, and like how each Terraria update di

Review: After finally obtaining all achievements for the game, it's time to actually write a review. First thoughts on Terraria was the stereotypical mentality that it's "Oh just another Minecraft clone. Nothing special from something that rips off the original classic." However, after picking up the game(at the recommendation of a few friends who have tried and played/streamed the game), it was time to get into a game that has mostly positive reviews and high ratings. Now why would what is considered as "Another Minecraft rip-off" be so highly regarded and praised by the community?  It is clear that Terraria is not a Minecraft clone after a couple of hours into the game. Despite the fact that it has the same blocky concept of its "predecessor", most similarities end as there are many distinctions that can be made from it being 2D to its more "combat-system" focused style of farming.  What to like about the game: 1. It's fun. No really. You can sink hours into the game before you realise what time it is as there is so much to do and explore in the game. Like fighting bosses? They have anything from the Slime King and Queen Bee to The Eater of Worlds and Moon Lord. Only prefer to build? No problem, you can create a world that's solely dedicated to constructing your magnificent structures. Like fishing? Grab a rod, some bait and find a patch of water, honey or even lava to fish in! No matter what you want to do in-game, Terraria will have it all.  2. Classes. The 4 main classes most Terraria veterans will list down are Melee, Ranged, Mage and Summoner(RIP Thrower). You can easily pick any class early on but not devote to it as there is no "skill-tree" to put points into. Only your armor and choice of weapon would define your class. You could even go for hybrid-classes if you wish to! The only thing to take into consideration would be your level of expertise and preferred playstyle.  3. Two different modes. Terraria offers something Minecraft does not, a different difficulty setting you choose when you create a world. It offers a "normal" mode for newer players who are unused to the game (and don't want to die at the start) and an "expert" mode for players who wish to have a more "challenging" experience. Why go for the expert option? Well, it offers more money upon defeating enemies and it even has exclusive loot which can only be obtained in this level of difficulty. With the release of the final update of Terraria, a new "Master" mode will be added and be the highest level of the game for players to challenge themselves with.  Cons: 1. Terraria must seem like such a great game right? However, it does have one thing that may put players off: Grinding. Grinding for materials or items will seem tedious to some especially with the low drop-rates and RNGesus messing with players.  2. Its end-game. After you've "finished" the game, it may seem like the game has offered everything it can. As such, it may be boring for players to play alone in Singleplayer, so it would be better for them to play on Multiplayer servers or with friends(If you don't have any who play this game yet, try and encourage them to!). Or you could also download any of the mods they have to completely revamp the game and have a new playing experience!  All in all, Terraria is a great game that will offer countless hours of entertainment.

Review: I love this game! What I love about it is that it is fairly easy and low-key when you first start, so you can learn how to play the game and find stuff without being overwelmed, but is still challenging. I played this game with a friend and he gave me a basic rundown of what you do in the game, but if you come into the game completely new, it can be confusing to know what you are actually suppose to do. You have to explore your world to gain any stuff, and as you gain more stuff you also risk finding bad creatures and eventually a boss. As your character gets stronger the game gets harder, but it still never feels impossible to complete. I also like that you can play this game over and over and still find new things to do, it never really feels completed to me. I have over 400 hrs in this game and I still haven't completed Duke Fishtron or Moon Lord on hardmode. I really like building towns and castles, you can make farms and machines, completely explore your map, dig tunnels and elevators to get around quickly, and you can build battle towers and test them by summoning events like the Blood/Frost/Pumpkin moon. Once you have your character built up as much as you can you can also do hardmode and expert, both are very challenging and fun. It is kind of funny how quickly you defeat the low level bosses like the Eye of Cthulhu once you are really strong. If you have a really powerful summoner active, sometimes they can kill the small bosses before they even appear in your field of vision.  You can play with/against friends too, but getting the game actually set up and able to play multi-player is kind of a hastle, but once you have it figured out is is a lot of fun. The game also has a cheeky sense of sarcasim and adult humor that never gets old.  Overall I love the game, it is easily one of my favorites!

Review: Terraria is a game of trial and error. If your only experience thus far with sandbox survival is Minecraft, then you will have a bit of a learning curve when jumping in.  Almost nothing is told to the player upon starting out--you have one other soul who spawns in beside you, and if you don't talk to him and heed his advice on how to get going, then you can expect a lot of fumbling. That's not to say it isn't fun stumbling into caves and dying in frustrating ways, but you soon get items that you don't quite know what to do with, you don't know to start building a base that will attract new NPCs (or what those requirements are), and even then, your resources are slim. Most are reusable, but you don't know that from the outset.  Your first world or two is going to look ugly. Trudging through the different biomes and figuring out how to get to new areas without dying, or how to mine ore and turn it into ingots, without looking at the Wiki once? If you can figure it out, then you have a better chance at survival.  I truly, truly love this game, but I understand that it is NOT very easy for new players unless you just throw yourself at it and are okay with failure. Don't worry about money at the start, you'll make plenty of it later--don't be the hero. You don't drop items upon death, just money. Play with every new item you get. Look at every icon on your HUD and inventory, talk to the Guide. Don't be afraid to click on anything, even if it looks like a trap (it might be a trap).  I play solo, but I know this game is even more fun with friends around to help figure it out. You can get really creative with item loadouts and customization, it just takes time to get there. Go out, start digging, and uhhh don't worry about the moon. It's fine.

Review: I sometimes find myself envying people who sit down to play an outstanding video game for the first time. It's like a Christmas morning: putting the toy back under the tree and tearing opening the box all over again will never quite replicate the excitement of seeing it for the first time. Terraria is this sort of game. Starting a new world with a new character still feels like an exciting adventure, but the experience of stepping into that bright two-dimensional world for the first time, and discovering piece-by-piece all that it has hidden, is worth the asking price all by itself. Subsequent playthroughs only add to the value, and how! And if it's on sale - it is, often - I can only advise you not to hesitate.  Terraria is a very versatile game. You can play for hours at a time, clocking up days' worth of play, and still have a 'to-do' list as long as a Bone Serpent. Alternatively, you can casually dip in and out when the mood suits you, building a little here, digging a little there, working on some great artifice a bit at a time. You can challenge gods and monsters with the finest weaponry crafted from the rarest metals, or simply make a treehouse for all your NPC friends with matching furniture sets and mood lighting. Become an arctic explorer! Go fishing! Drain the ocean into the dungeon! (I have actually done this, it was hard work but good fun.) Go to hell - literally! You can try to be bored, but it will take a lot of effort.  One of the advantages Terraria has over so many other games is the involvement of a dedicated development team. When updates come - and they may not come forever - they add great stores of content to the game, with new NPCs, items, mechanics, enemies and locations, not to mention all the tweaks and fixes which aim at keeping everything balanced, no small feat given that every change has to keep Terraria accessible to new players, whilst offering bigger and better challenges to existing players whose kingdoms span from ocean to ocean. This is all done remarkably well: the devs maintain a good community, and there is always the sense that the players are being listened to when new content arrives, without ever compromising the creative vision behind it. In an age of cowboy developers, corporate spin and micro-transactions on every street corner, Terraria is a welcome example of good practice in video games, and if I needed to buy it again, I would quite happily pay the full price - although, as I said, sales do happen.  Of course, nothing is perfect, and nothing is for everyone. When it comes to armour and weapons, and things forged out of fantastically rare ores, it can be very 'grindy' (if that's a word). Building anything of any real size takes time, as does the collection of large quantities of wood and stone and whatever else you may be using to put together your palace. Boss fights can take a lot of preparation, and the later-stage bosses can feel genuinely punishing when attempted repeatedly. As a rule, I find that Terraria is very good at compensating for these issues, (a quick trip to collect wood for house-building can turn into a hectic race through zombie-infested tundra, or an expedition to recover unknown loot from the bottom of some murky chasm,) but not everyone will want to give it their time. A mere two dimensions may be a deal-breaker for some, not to mention the rather old-school, pixel-y art style. But even if this sounds like you, I recommend giving it a try. For me, Terraria worked where Minecraft didn't, and I still feel that the former deserves some of the credit that is typically heaped upon the latter. So give it a go, walk around that forest for the first time, dig a little below the surface and see if the spirit of adventure takes you. If it does, keep digging - after one year and 262 hours of play, I still haven't stopped.

Review: Oddly enough, Terraria was the first game I'd bought on Steam. I had been away from PC gaming for a fair amount of time and a good friend had discovered the game on SA and started pestering me to play. The buy in was dirt cheap and it looked mighty weird with it's retro chic graphics, but I figured if said friend was so fired up about it, I might as well give it ago. All of the praise I could find at the time compared it to Minecraft, so I was a bit leary. I'd watched my kid play hours of Minecraft and it just wasn't my bag. I'm glad I was able to push that stigma aside, because I ended up finding a gem of a game that pulled me away from my fancy consoles for a good chunk of time.  We've all been kids; kids love to explore. Exploration is the foundation of Terraria. You start out with nothing more than a pick axe and a large map, then you're left with simply trying to figure out what's there. Start to dig, maybe build a house and you're off and running.  There's something mentally satisfying about being able to click away at the soft earth, digging a path ever deeper. It may seem pointless, but as you tunnel down, maybe you take a jog to your right and all of a sudden a hidden cave opens up before you. Dig some more, perhaps you find an underground lake. Maybe after a few hours of digging, you find something far more sinister. Then, you spice things up by spinning up a server and letting your friends join you, and now you're working in conjunction, worming your way through the contryside with a misdrected sense of manifest destiny, coupled with the thrill of shouting 'ooh, look what I found!' and getting them to come see.  Terraria's not flashy, but it doesn't need to be. It's a relaxing good time and it'll bring you a wee bit of the childhood joy of exploring.

Review: Terraria is a 2D RPG with building and crafting elements and some limited exploration. The primary goal of the game is to improve your gear and take on progressively difficult bosses. Along the way you will have to manage NPC's housing and towns, build structures for defence, utility and housing, mine ore and continue to craft better armours, weapons and equipment to face these escalating challenges. You will also have to deal with cleansing (or keeping at bay) corruption/crimson (depending on your generated world), which is an evil biome that spreads throughout your world. Later on you will contend with additional biomes and the challenges they bring.  Graphically it has a simple, yet pleasing aesthetic, reminiscent of "old-school" 16-bit platformers. It's beautiful in its own way and has the advantage of being able to run on pretty much anything. Sound and music are equally as fitting - and the whole package fits really well together.  The game also has a sandbox element to it, where you can just ignore objectives and build, explore or do whatever you want. Your character is independent of a world and can freely move between them, meaning you can create a world for building magnificent structures only if that's what you want, and have another focused towards completion. Worlds are randomly generated based on a seed with a few options including difficulty and world size, along with the choice of crimson or corruption, which are different versions of the evil biome that spawn different monsters, items and bosses.  There are 4 different classes that you will eventually be swayed to move into, including melee, ranged, magic or summoning. Each of these offer very different playstyles, powers and weapons. There should be something here for everyone - and hybrid classes are possible should you wish. There is no level up or experience system. Your character progresses by getting better equipment. This also means you can farm equipment for all classes and switch between them when you wish.  It features multiplayer - both with dedicated servers and drop-in-out play via Steam. It is great fun to play with friends, where you can team up to take on challenges or just let your creativity free and make the fun for yourself.  There is a lot to see and do here, giving it immense replay value and the gameplay loop is addictive and fun. Anyone interested in RPG's, sandboxes, crafting and building should give it a go as it may surprise you with just how well made the game is.

Review: Not often do I review games I enjoy, but the mindless wave of negative reviews has made me want to write SOMETHING.  Terraria is a game of passion, obvious from the decade the developers have spent updating and improving on the already-solid framework. It features some of the best 2-D combat I've ever experienced, a gorgeous art style, and a very satisfying progression.  All this is not to mention the countless high quality fan-made mods - Calamity, Thorium, and many others add dozens (if not hundreds) of extra hours of gameplay. The players are just as passionate about this game as the developers.  Most negative reviews (at the time of writing) don't criticize the game itself, rather the fact the devs don't share their political ideologies. It's disappointingly childish. While the game does have its flaws, don't look to these reviews for them right now.  If, by some off-chance, you are reading this and have never played the game, try it out! It may introduce you to a new favorite! Don't let the drama scare you off.

Review: Introduction Terraria is a pixelized sandbox survival game originally released in 2011. It has a long history of success, being released on multiple different gaming platforms and receiving free content updates across the decade up to this very day. Just recently, the devs teamed up with Don‚Äôt Starve developers Klei to create a major crossover event between both games. At first glance, you may be tempted to compare Terraria to be a 2D Minecraft, but oh boy are you wrong. Truth be told, reviewing this game is not an easy task, since its best to experience it with as little prior knowledge as possible. As such, I will try to keep potential spoilers to a minimum and will focus on the more general outline of this game.   The basic idea is survival ‚Äì build your first home, weapons, tools ‚Äì everything you need for your continuous adventures throughout the beautiful random generated worlds Terraria offers. The game can be played (and finished!) solo or with friends and while the UI may feel aged at times, the huge amounts of customization options in the vanilla game can always be expanded using mods. Together with your friends, you will explore deep mushroom caverns, deserts filled with treacherous traps and even reach for the sky, all of these representing only a glimpse of the unique biomes contained within this game. Gathering useful loot and making many new friends along your path, while occasionally struggling with one or the other tougher foe, until you reach a foul and devastated land‚Ä¶   This land is dark, filled with stench and monstrous enemies and represents one of the many surprises this game holds in stock for the new player. While you previously travelled beautiful fields filled with sunflowers under a blue sky, this biome is full of death and decay. Direct story telling is not something Terraria will try to convey. Instead, the player must focus on gathering clues, making friends and progressing through the various biomes to unravel the many secrets this mysterious land holds. This will ultimately kickstart a series of events subliminally guiding the players journey throughout the game.   While the pixel art style may be off-putting at first, it is in fact very charming and allows Terraria to visualize both extremely pleasant as well as dark biomes incredibly well. The world in general feels highly dynamic, with certain events (such as rain) causing a series of event-specific mobs to spawn (e.g. enemies carrying umbrellas). The sound design of this game is particularly fantastic. Every biome song slaps. Hard. At times this will suit the games laid-back atmosphere well, but it can also significantly increase your pulse during high tension boss battles.   In conclusion, Terraria is an awesome survival experience for solo players or together with friends. While time is slowly taking its toll, the game is still tons of fun and features in-depth crafting mechanics, customization options, mod support, random world generation and unlimited replayability. Terraria arguably should have received the Steam-Award 2020 for the continuous support of the indie development studio behind it and especially since it received its major Journey‚Äôs End update last year, but lost to Counter Strike: Global Offensive in a head on head fight. I say, let‚Äôs give Terraria the Steam Award it deserves, let‚Äôs show the devs our appreciation and celebrate Terrarias 10 year anniversary together!    Game voted for the Steam-Award 2021.

Review: Minecraft had a love-child with Metroid and they called it Terrarria.  It‚Äôs a 2D Action-Platformer, bullet hell, survival game in a procedurally generated world. It features different Biomes, Mobs, Bosses, a slew of mechanics and most importantly‚Ä¶ loot. So MUCH god d a m n loot! Hidden everywhere in the world, as boss drops, as rare-drops etc.  It has crafting and building mechanics, just like Minecraft. Your gear gradually improves as you progress for you to be able to face ever more dangerous enemies.  You can either play on baby difficulty with God mode or die about as much as Dark Souls on the hardest difficulty.  It‚Äôs single or multiplayer - there are multiple world sizes. You can host worlds, or join a server.  In short: It‚Äôs glorious.  There‚Äôs not a single person on planet Earth who doesn‚Äôt enjoy Terrarria so you‚Äôre doing yourself a disservice by not playing it.  10/10

Review: Terraria has revealed itself as a very complete game. Review: After putting hundreds and hundreds of hours into this game, A review: The basic game has been developed a lot through it's lifetime, and is very solid. There are a few overpowered things here and there (such as the very early obtained gem grappling hooks with massive range) but it's a very solid balance over all. Lots of objects you will find will already be useless because you've found better, but each time you play through the game, who knows, you might just happen upon an item earlier than usual. What you'll want to play this game for is the multiplayer. Playing alone is all well and good, but playing with friends, building projects with them, that's what can't be beaten. The bosses are incredibly difficult to beat alone anyway, so it'll make your life a lot easier to work with others. I seem to always manage to get a lot more hours from this game every time someone new decides they'll play it with me.  Finally, a suggestion. 1. Get this game. 2. Play on a LARGE world. Small worlds run out of space to explore quickly, and it'll mean anything you build isn't kept, because when you finish exploring a world, you'll want to go to another. Sky islands will be more difficult to find, and you'll have to build outposts close to the dungeon and the jungle so you don't keep having to run from your original spawn, but it's worth it. It'll also mean the corruption won't spread over your house as quickly once you get into hardmode.

Review: In the beginning, without knowing anything about to the game, it may seem boring and somewhat dull, just like it was for me. But it turned out I was very wrong thinking in such way, after I got slightly further into the game, which had me devoured fully. The way progression works in Terraria is such a satisfying process to go through, even if sometimes, it my get a bit grindy, be it the bosses or or looting tons of materials. Hours of non-stop playing were spent on it, and I fully admit that it was worth it! In addition to that, I hope that new players of the game, that have never seen it before won't stop after an hour of first time gameplay, because the seemingly boring beginning will eventually turn out into a very fun, long and entertaining journey, full of various emotions on the way. It is a perfect example of "not judging a book by its cover," at least for my personal experience.

Review: There are plenty of positive reviews of this game and with good reason. Terraria is certainly one of my favourite games ever. There is a huge amount of content and the game suits many different types of player. It's a game for those who want to explore, those who want to build, fight bosses or hunt for loot. I think almost everyone can enjoy this game once they find the way to play that they enjoy the most. One warning that I would give is that care must be taken when introducing new players to the game. When someone plays by themselves they can play at their own rate and go about obstacles in their own way (such as a guide on the internet). An experienced player may progress too quickly and overwhelm a new player to the point where they become disinterested. They should be allowed to progress the game at their own rate and guided as to what needs to be done when they become stuck. As well as this, introducing multiple people to Terraria at once has also proved difficult in my experience. People tend to want to do their own thing in an open game like Terraria and may miss out on important parts of progression. Of course, this depends on the people you are playing with and you can make your judgement based on their tendencies. Once they are up to speed however, the game becomes that much more enjoyable for everyone. Overall, despite having said more on the learning curve of the game for new players, I truly believe this game is brilliant and worth a try from just about everybody.

Review: -Accepted by the Leguminati-  My sister played this for hours and I always wondered why. Finally I received this game, I believe my brother purchased it for me. I played. I built a house in a cave. I had a chainsaw. My brother had bombs. My name was Zen.  My brother used bombs. In my house cave. By ‚Äòaccident.‚Äô  He didn‚Äôt tell me, he tried to cover it up and put everything back the way he found it. He did pretty good. But I knew something was off. Ever since then I have hidden my bombs from him.  Then, I visited his world. His world boated a huge apartment complex. Half underground as there was a huge hill on one side of it. I would never use bombs on his house. Not even by accident. I placed my bombs in my inventory so I didn‚Äôt accidentally use them in a quick slot.  I had wings. I flew into the skies. I found a cloud. A cloud full of water. I had an idea.  His village was destined for a‚Ä¶ different type of revenge. All of my siblings made buckets. We made buckets with the iron of my brother‚Äôs world. We scooped water from everywhere. We hollowed out the cloud and filled it with water.  My brother, the bomb wielding maniac, maybe he didn‚Äôt deserve this fate. In fact, I know he didn‚Äôt. He didn‚Äôt mean to blow up my cave house. He tried to fix it. But filling a cloud with buckets and buckets of water was just too fun.  ‚ÄúCome to your village!‚Äù I told him.  He came. And the flood began.  I can still remember his sad, confused cries of despair as water flooded his homes. He closed the doors where he could to stop the damage. Torches and tiki torches came off the walls. Water. Water everywhere.  He was such a good sport. He didn‚Äôt fight or scream or curse or call me names. He laughed.  I felt bad. He tried to fix what he had done to my home and I flooded his and he laughed.  Living in fear and shame I returned to my world of ‚ÄòZen‚Äôs World.‚Äô I had to do something.  Someone doesn‚Äôt just laugh at their flooded world without plans of revenge.  I had to flood proof my home.  First, I dug deep down. Halfway to the underground. I hollowed out a massive chunk of land and called it a water pit. I made holes in the floors of my houses that would drain down into this massive pit. Ha. Flood proof. Revenge proof.  In the following weeks, when I tried to load into my world. The file was corrupt.  Zen‚Äôs World was broken. I tried everything.  Oh well. I made a new world. Sad Land. I knew my first goal. It was to make a water pit. A bigger, deeper, fuller water pit. It took days to dig it. Maybe weeks. I decided to make it a little nicer. I lined it in stone slab and made platforms every ten blocks so that it was noob friendly. It had lights in air bubbles to light the water. A new house in a cave. This one had a tower for the wizard to move into. It was made of bricks and it had a chimney. It had cobwebs and mossy stone. It had a crystal ball.  I made the drain pipes lead down into the water pit. My home was flood proof. Revenge proof.  A few weeks later, I logged into my world. My character was corrupt! This was terrible. Everything I had collected from this world and the last was gone. My gold, my platinum. My pet dinosaur. My molten pickaxe.  It‚Äôs fine. I needed a new character to help me figure out how to do things completely fresh. My new character was named Xen.  Hello Xen! Welcome to Sad Land. Only, not. Sad Land was corrupt, too.  I was sad. I was the sad land now. Well‚Ä¶ all that was left to do was to make a new world. I wanted to see the best in making a new character. It was hard. But now I had to see the best in making a new world, too.  Welcome to California Land, Xen.  I dug a water pit. A massive water pit. With a copper pickaxe. I dug to the underground. It was over 120 blocks wide. It was framed with 5 blocks of brick all around. It took forever.  I showed my siblings. I built a big city.  We beat the bosses. Pirate invasions. Goblin armies. We sacrificed Jeff to the lava god. We beat the mechanical bosses, all at once. We beat Plantera after coming to the realization we needed to make a stadium. We dug a huge arena and beat the mean flower.  We beat the Golem after the traps brutally dissected us all. We spent hours navigating that treacherous territory.  Feeling accomplished, we went back to the village with our loot.  I decided to do some fisherman quests and went to the sea.  On my way there I saw these‚Ä¶ these things! Cultists! Worshiping the‚Ä¶ the wall! I panicked. I shot them. I screamed and cried and I was tired from playing for so long already but I was scared.  My siblings ran to help me but by the time they got there the Cultists were dead.  And something terrifying happens.  Four terrible towers that spawned the strongest enemies we had ever seen appeared across my world. I was sure they were slowing moving towards the middle. My village! My village was flood proof not the end of the world proof!  I panicked! I begged for their help! We had to get my people to a safe place. We took them down above the water pit. In the underground. We teleported them there using the steampunk‚Äôs teleporter. Some in groups, some one at a time.  We realized the towers weren‚Äôt moving. But it didn‚Äôt matter. WE destroyed my village. It was in shambles. What flood mattered now that my people lived in tiny homes carved out of rock miles below the surface?  It didn‚Äôt matter. Revenge meant nothing now. Still, I remembered what I had done to my brother‚Äôs world. I apologized and thanked him for helping save my people from what I thought was sure death.  Eventually, we beat those towers. But we weren‚Äôt prepared for what came afterwards. The Moon Lord.  He completely destroyed us. We were in awe.  We knew what we had to do. We began farming the Golem to trigger the Cultists to spawn the Towers to farm the drops for their armor. This took eternity. We would fight the final tower and let the Moon Lord kill us so we could start over.  Then, when we all bore full sets of armor and weapons, we were ready. We made a railroad track that spanned the entire world. It had boosters pushing the opposite way at the end to propel us in the other direction.  I was the mana lord. Flower was the sun lord. Max (the mad bomber) was the pet master. Din was the gun master.  We fought the Towers one last time. And we won. The Moon Lord was dead. My ruined world was saved and we were OP and ready to do anything. We had platinum to buy anything. We had materials to make everything. And most importantly, we had fun with each other.  Flower was going to built a charizard in the sky out of painted blocks as a sign of our victory.  Then‚Ä¶ the world was corrupted. What was worse‚Ä¶ Xen was corrupted.  Everything was gone. I had nothing. I was broken. I lost. My cobalt digging claws, my unicorn, my mana armor, my everything‚Ä¶ gone. My people‚Ä¶ gone.  I quit. For a long time. No more Terraria.  Until there was.  I quit for about seven months and started up again and accepted the idea that I might lose everything.  Carnie was born. The world Tight Rope was created.  This time I focused on upgrading everything. Finding everything. Finishing all the achievements. I wasn‚Äôt going to quit Terraria until I had finished Terraria. I got the Ankh Charm and the PDA. I had hallowed armor and a fur cloak.  And then it happened.  Corrupt world. Corrupt Carnie.  I was sad, but not yet broken again. I had worked hard for that little fishing punk to get my PDA‚Ä¶ and I‚Äôll do it again. I‚Äôll do it all again. I‚Äôll flood proof my town, even though Max never wanted revenge. And I‚Äôll still play with my siblings and another sibling. The Prune Lord.  Today, corrupt files are a thing of the past. There are so many more memories I could share but there‚Äôs no more room.  Yes. Buy Terraria. Play with friends. Lose everything‚Ä¶ and still have fun.  The Leguminati on Steam - Join now!

Review: Terraria is a small 2D adventure game. I will review the game in some paragraphs, and then I will give it 1-10 points.  [Gameplay] In the beggining, your quest it's to find wood, and make a shelter to survive the first night. "The First Night"-that was the longest nigh in Terraria for me. Then, the game starts getting harder and harder. There are zombies, slimes, skeletones, Bosses and many, many other creatures. It's very interesting game! 10/10  [Crafting] Ah.The crafting system in this game is quet hard to solve.It was hard to me, I didn't know even how to make a torch. The coolest thing about the crafting system is that, you only need the items for the thing you want to craft, not like in Minecraft, where you need to put every material in some "speacial" position. If you're a new player, talk to the first person you see in the game. Just do it!!! 9/10 It was hard...  [Bosses] This is the coolest part of the game. Beating the bosses! So, The Bosses are made on 2 difficults, Easy and Hard. If you fight on easy difficult, don't worry. The Bosses have like 2k HP to 10k HP. They can be easly beaten up with a good armor and good weapons. IF YOU ARE A NEW PLAYER DON'T START WITH THE HARDMODE! JUST DON'T!!! On Hard mode, the Bosses are very hard, and If you die, you lose the game... Ex. The Eye Of Cthulhu it's on 2,8k HP on Easy, but on Hard mode, the Eyes are two and their name is "The Twins" The one have 20k, the other 23k HP. Good luck! 11/10  [Multiplayer] Oh my God. This is the game I can play with friends forever! It's very funny and when you and the crew get all on HardMode characters and start beating bosses, it's cool. The worstest thig is that, Terraria is made on Small, Medium and Large terrain. This is the worstest thing, not like in Minecraft, to be infinite. But it's a'ight. 8.5/10 Can be better.  [Final Review] "Terraria" is a very good game. Even better than Minecraft, lol. So BUY it, what're ya' waiting for? This is an big adventure in a small world, which can be played with friends. What more do you need? 9.5/10 - I highly recommend this game!  *Sorry for my bad english!*

Review: After playing for a bit, i can say that people who call Terraria 2D Minecraft are wrong. Terraria is better than Minecraft for several reasons. First and foremost, Terraria offers a more immersive and challenging gameplay experience. With a wide variety of enemies, bosses, and events, players are constantly engaged and on their toes. Additionally, Terraria's crafting system allows for endless possibilities, as players can combine various materials and items to create unique weapons, armour, and tools. Furthermore, Terraria has a stronger focus on exploration. The world of Terraria is massive and filled with hidden treasures, secret biomes, and dungeons to discover. This encourages players to venture out and uncover new areas, making each playthrough exciting and unpredictable. Moreover, Terraria's multiplayer aspect is seamless and highly enjoyable. Whether playing with friends or joining an online community, Terraria offers a cooperative gameplay experience like no other. Players can team up to defeat challenging bosses, build epic structures, and even engage in PvP battles. Another aspect where Terraria surpasses Minecraft is its robust and frequent updates. The developers consistently release new content, introducing exciting features, items, and events, which keeps the game fresh and enjoyable for long-time players. This commitment to regular updates ensures that players always have something new to look forward to. Lastly, Terraria's pixelated art style and retro aesthetics are visually appealing and nostalgic.  if you are wanting a game to spend hundreds of hours in, Terraria is perfect and i highly suggest trying it out with friends. Even if you have none its still fun alone.

Review: 476 hours is not accurate. Through Xbox 360, Xbox One, and PC, I have over 1500 hours on this game. I played when Ocram was still in the game. You used to be able to find Dragon Armor at the bottom of pits in the Corruption. I moved to PC back in 2016, and I still remember my first time fighting the 4 pillars. This game is my absolute favorite game I've ever played.  This game tells a story, and lets you play through that story in your own way over and over again. The multiplayer is amazing, even running solo is still fun. The crafting takes you to new areas constantly, letting you discover new enemies, and find new characters to help you on your journey. And the boss fights are heart racing, plus give you amazing rewards and great satisfaction.  There really is no game like this game. I just wish I could experience it again as a child and remember how filled with adventure I felt.  10/10

Review: Good Game.  At face value, Terraria is just a 2D version of Minecraft. But if you continue playing, you will soon realize how different these games are. Terraria has more ores, more items, and different mechanics. That doesn't make Terraria any better or worse, just different. Minecraft is a completely different game from Terraria. Both games have the same basic idea, but they expand on it in very different ways. Both games are very different experiences, and shouldn't even be compared.

Review: Terraria, the 2D sandbox game that has captivated millions of players since its release, continues to prove its status as a timeless masterpiece. As I dive into its pixelated world, I find myself lost in a world of boundless exploration, thrilling battles, and endless creativity. It is with great pleasure that I share my experiences, as Terraria unquestionably deserves recognition as one of the greatest games on Steam.  First and foremost, Terraria's vast and diverse world is nothing short of awe-inspiring. From lush forests to treacherous caverns and sprawling deserts, every corner of this pixelated realm is teeming with secrets waiting to be discovered. The game expertly balances a sense of adventure and discovery, rewarding players with rare treasures and formidable foes at every turn. The thrill of unearthing ancient artifacts or stumbling upon hidden underground dungeons never ceases to amaze.  The depth of gameplay in Terraria is astonishing. With a seemingly infinite array of crafting options, players are only limited by their own imagination. From humble wooden abodes to towering fortresses adorned with gleaming treasures, the game allows you to shape the world as you see fit. The sense of accomplishment in building something truly remarkable is immeasurable, and sharing your creations with others online is a joy in itself.  Combat in Terraria is both exhilarating and challenging. The variety of weapons and armor available ensures that each encounter feels fresh and engaging. Whether facing off against massive bosses that test your skill and strategy or embarking on perilous journeys with friends, the game provides an adrenaline rush like no other. The cooperative multiplayer experience, whether local or online, is seamless and adds a whole new dimension of enjoyment to the game.  The artistic design of Terraria, with its charming pixelated graphics, pays homage to the classic games of the past while maintaining a unique and captivating aesthetic. The attention to detail is evident in every pixel, from the way sunlight filters through the trees to the subtle animations that breathe life into the world. The game's enchanting soundtrack further elevates the immersive experience, creating a harmonious fusion of visuals and audio that transports players to another realm entirely.  Terraria's dedicated development team, consistently delivering updates and new content over the years, deserves applause. Their commitment to enhancing the game and keeping it fresh has resulted in a loyal and passionate player community that continues to grow. The frequent updates and expansion packs have added hours upon hours of additional gameplay, ensuring that Terraria remains a game that never gets old.  In conclusion, Terraria stands as a shining example of the brilliance that can be achieved in the realm of indie gaming. Its boundless creativity, exhilarating gameplay, and captivating world make it a masterpiece that deserves the highest accolades. If you seek an adventure that will both challenge and inspire you, look no further than Terraria. Prepare to embark on a journey that will leave an indelible mark on your gaming soul. Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vZuRyhPjr3c  Overview Even 7 years later this two-dimensional survival game still piques my interest. I have already spent hundreds of hours mining, building, gearing, fighting massive bosses and I could easily spend hundreds more due to the thriving modding community. Even though actual developer game updates are sparse, they do still continue working on new features and fixes, as well as porting and providing updates to console and mobile versions of the game.  Although some believe Terraria derives some inspiration from Minecraft, it is important to distinguish the major differences. These differences very much so separate Terraria as its own genre-defining experience. Terraria has a large focus on gear and boss progression. In the beginning this progression is very basic and mostly boils down to digging enough to find ores to make the next tier pickaxe. Later on progression becomes much deeper with a wide selection of options.  You can focus on magic, melee, ranged, summons, and you can take advantage of all sorts of special effects like invisibility or even flight. There are certainly some items that are not quite as useful as others, but there is such a massive amount of different items to choose from that you will certainly be able to create a character that plays exactly the way you want. If you‚Äôre feeling a gap in your build, or you‚Äôve just played through vanilla Terraria too many times already, it‚Äôs very easy to find a massive amount more variety in items through the game‚Äôs modding system.  The other important and incredibly fun part of progression in Terraria is the boss fights. You will often advance through the bosses in order alongside your gear progression. Some gear are found, or crafted from exploring the world, however bosses are usually a more important milestone for your equipment. Bosses often drop key components or fully functioning items that generally prove to be much more powerful than anything you‚Äôd be using before it. Because of this, many bosses are much more easily defeated using loot obtained from previous boss encounters.  I quite enjoy the sandbox nature of the game, however it certainly comes with a fairly annoying issue. There isn‚Äôt really a clear way to figure out how to do certain things ingame. And when these ‚Äúhidden‚Äù things are required for progressing it can get frustrating. This frustration can be easily remedied by visiting the game‚Äôs community wiki. It covers pretty much anything you could want to know about the game, and the playerbase is very good at keeping it up to date. If browsing the wiki isn‚Äôt appealing to you, there are several mods out there that make for a good replacement. I would highly recommend checking out ‚ÄúBoss Checklist‚Äù for a quick and clear list for keeping track of what bosses you‚Äôve defeated and which you should fight next.  You play in randomly generated worlds of limited size with varying features, but you are encouraged to bring your character across multiple different worlds throughout progression. You have options for character customization but it is quite limited as your character is just a small 2D sprite. While you are exploring your world you will be fighting off hordes of monsters, bosses, gathering loot, and building homes for yourself and your friendly NPCs. The vanilla experience easily gives hundreds of hours of play, but if you take it a step further and bring friends or find some fun mods, you will easily bring on hundreds more hours of enjoyment.  The UI is still largely the same as it‚Äôs been for many years, but it gets the job done. It‚Äôs very clear, very familiar if you‚Äôve played Minecraft, but still easy to learn and get used to if not. There are a good amount of choices for customizing quality of life options which is appreciated. Default controls work just fine for me playing on Mouse and Keyboard, and it has good controller support as well. All controls can be easily rebinded for either control scheme.  As it‚Äôs a 2D pixel-art game I can‚Äôt speak much to the impressiveness of the graphical fidelity, however I can say that the game runs well even when there are many monsters and particles on the screen at the same time. And even though the art style is somewhat basic, they have done a good job of creating their own unique aesthetic with the theme of their monsters and bosses. I believe the majority of people would easily be able to recognize a sprite from this game, even long after they‚Äôd stopped playing it. Also to be noted, there are plenty of graphical options to customize how your game looks or help it run better.  Overall quality of the audio is good, I wish there were a bit more options for tuning volumes or being able to mute certain things, but overall it‚Äôs not a big deal. The sound effects aren‚Äôt particularly amazing and some of them can get a big jarring such as when you‚Äôre constantly firing a laser pistol and hearing constant ‚Äúpew-pew-pewing‚Äù in your ears. I usually turn the effects down a bit and just enjoy the incredible music in the game instead. Terraria‚Äôs OST is certainly one of my favorites, and I‚Äôd recommend giving it a listen even if you don‚Äôt play the game.  Modding to some people tends to scare them away and think they‚Äôre going to get banned or break their game, but often that‚Äôs not even a risk. Modding in Terarria is allowed and it is very easy! There‚Äôs a plugin called ‚ÄúTerraria Mod Loader‚Äù that allows for very simple browsing and adding of mods to your game. I would highly recommend looking into this after you‚Äôve played through vanilla Terraria a couple times. There is a massive amount of mods out there for this game, and there are still more being made and improved right now.  Terraria truly is a genre-defining game in my eyes, I believe it had help growing to fame riding on Minecraft‚Äôs popularity wave, but it stands strong being one of the games that many others that have come after it have pulled inspiration from. Terraria is a 2D survival game, that combines gear progression, survival, fast paced boss fights, leisurely building, and many other activities that come together for a unique experience that I haven‚Äôt seen anywhere else. For the price, I have absolutely every reason to recommend this game to anyone that might be even remotely interested. I know that even years from now I will still continue to come back and spend hundreds hours more in this wonderful game.

Review: Product received for free  Terraria - My Honest Review The game was quite fun from the start, im not gonna lie, the grind was REAL, but it was enjoyable. There is a balanced amount of combat and grind. You're always grinding to obtain better weapons, armor, or anything else of the sort, but its always for a reason, be it you're struggling to defeat a tough boss, or you just want to get stronger. Is the game difficult? it wasn't for me, but i found it quite exhilarating at times, like when i got spawned the same night i defeated the Wall of Flesh, and i was unprepared. Let me tell you, i did not win.  I have currently defeated Moonlord and am now achievement hunting (as of writing this review, 97/115] even after you're finished with the game, theres always secret seeds and the modding community is quite active and you can always go for mods like Calamity or Starlight River.

Review: This is one of the best indie game masterpieces to ever exist. The gameplay, although a little annoying at times, keeps itself interesting and simple. I've been addicted to this game ever since I was 8 years old, and it affected a major part of my child hood. The game itself isn't too hard, (although you can increase and decrease it's difficulty!) but is a little bit complicated. I can also definitely tell the dev's didn't take this game too seriously with its silly references, enemy and boss concepts, and just generally a goofy take at some pixel art. For $10, this game is a steal. I still haven't fully completed 100% of the achievements on my steam account despite having over 500 hours in the game. Very replayable, with a ton of secret worlds and easter eggs to discover. I might be a bit biased due to having a nostalgic connection to the game, but it seriously does deserve your time and money. 11/10.

Review: Welcome to the fantastic game Terraria! This game is an absolute blast and can keep you entertained for hours. It is a 2D sandbox game developed by Re-Logic available on almost every platform imaginable including PC, Xbox, PlayStation, Nintendo Switch and even mobile.  Terraria is an adventure game with a variety of different game mechanics. The game begins with your character being thrown into a procedurally generated world with nothing but a few basic tools and weapons. From there, it's up to you to explore the vast and mysterious world, find resources, craft new items, and construct your own unique structures.  One of the things I love most about Terraria is the game's extensive crafting system. There are hundreds of different items you can craft, from simple tools and weapons to magical potions and enchanted armor. The crafting system is intuitive and easy to use, but also allows for a lot of creativity and experimentation.  Another standout feature of Terraria is the game's bosses. There are dozens of different bosses to fight, each with their own unique attacks and strategies. Some of the bosses are huge and require careful planning and preparation to defeat, while others are smaller and more manageable. Each boss drops unique loot, so it's always worth defeating them.  In addition to the main adventure mode, Terraria also has a multiplayer mode that allows you to play with friends. You can explore the world together, help each other fight bosses, and construct massive structures together.  The graphics and sound in Terraria are also fantastic. The game has a charming 2D pixel style that looks great and is incredibly expressive. The music is good too, with a wide variety of different tracks that perfectly capture the adventurous spirit of the game.  Overall, Terraria is an incredibly fun and addictive game that I would recommend to anyone who enjoys sandbox-style adventure games. With its extensive crafting system, challenging bosses, and multiplayer, there's always something new and exciting to discover in Terraria.

Review: "2D Minecraft" - It is a thought almost everyone has had (and anyone claiming otherwise are lying to themselves), but Terraria is much more than just that, and here is why I recommend it.  Terraria's world is literally designed as a Terrarium, you start somewhere towards the middle of your world, and whether you go left or right - you will eventually stumble into an "ocean" with an invisible wall a little ways out. You have a couple options, build a base, and start exploring the surface, or you start mining and spelunking through the cave systems.  Terraria's surface contains a little less than a dozen different biomes for you to explore and utilize as grounds for your home base (or outpost), and you will stumble into various enemies throughout them, and even sometimes fight the biome itself (Cure the corruption/crimson, or heck even help it spread!). Be sure to build shelter for the night as monsters are prone to hunt you down. Additionally there is also the chance of events happening, such as the goblin invasion.  Throughout its underground system (which can be around 2000 blocks deep) you will find mini-dungeons, deep cavern systems and even bosses at times. And of course, we have a hell-ish biome at the very bottom filled with lava and demonic creatures.  And when you think you have done it all? Defeat the boss in the hell-biome and start a NewGame+ esque event that makes everything in your world harder - even the bosses.  So is Terraria recommended? Hell yes. For $10 (it's been on sale as low as $2 if you're on a budget) you will literally get days (or weeks!) worth of gameplay, and even more so if you have friends to play with! (Co-op always makes games better).

Review: Product received for free  Never thought that a text "Also play Terraria!" shown by Minecraft in-game title would bring me to such one of the most amazing games I've ever played.  I found Terraria about 8 years ago, from playing the old, cracked mobile version without hard mode until playing the PC version 1.4 today. I've replayed the game countless times, since by cracking you have to restart from zero if you want to update version. I'm glad I am able to support the devs by playing it on Steam now (even though I received it for free XD).  With the contents Terraria is able to provide, Terraria is extremely underpriced to the point that I worried once whether the devs have proper meal or not (glad that's not the case). And if you ever feel that the content is not enough, you can browse community-made mods and play for another 200 hours. Terraria is fun when you play it alone, but it is even more fun with friends. If you don't have friends to play Terraria with, you can visit open servers like Pedguin and play CTF or something.  The only disadvantage of playing Terraria is that you will become addicted. Make sure you also take care of your body besides your Terraria character's stats and what not. But, well, this issue is universal for every amazing game, isn't it?

Review: I am 42.  My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.  When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.  After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.  Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.  After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.  Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.  I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.  Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.  That's all , thank you.

Review: The developers of Terraria have never stopped updating the game with better graphics, better and more music and items, improvements to gameplay, and additional content for the entire lifetime of the game, despite updates being free to those who purchased the game...even as far back as its original release date. I'm convinced their self proclaimed final major update, "Journey's End", isn't even the end of this quality maintenance. Few games have this level of quality to begin with, but the developers are in a league of their own with their dedication to maintaining quality for their player base.  If you enjoy sandbox elements like those found in games like Minecraft, or exploration and progression like what is found in a "Metroidvania" game, then Terraria is a staple for your collection. The latest major update even adds a "Journey Mode", that lets players skip as much or as little "grinding" as they like, all while playing with the exact difficulty level they are comfortable with: in "Journey Mode", players have control over enemy strength, defense, health, and even their spawn rates.  Post Labor of Love update addendum: I actually don't like this new direction for Terraria.  They said they were done with major updates when Journey's End released, and left the game in a state that was a good balance between letting engineering players break the game, while also giving hardcore players something to sweat at. Now they're adding a bunch of difficulty changes for old content, and rebalancing a ton of things yet again, and it doesn't seem like they're even done with rebalancing things. Why do we need changes to old bosses when there's the tModLoader for booting up things like Calamity, and a whole new "Legendary" difficulty as part of a masochistic world seed that essentially adds new (arguably awful, but still) versions of every boss? Shouldn't it be more important to fix all of the network related race conditions that make the new promise of crossplay seem like a farce?  It's nice to have well thought out new content, like the new Shimmer liquid, but continuing to make balance changes to old content, while also regularly adding more new difficulty modifiers, for a game that seemed to be stable, just feels like the same impossible to enjoy endgame you get in online only games that never stop updating, where nothing you obtain or learn matters because it gets invalidated within weeks. The goalposts keep moving, and not in the fun and interesting way they did when they added more earlygame Summoner items or a whole new biome to bridge some of the gaps between item tiers.  Our Horseman's Blades can't summon a ton of homing pumpkins from statues anymore? Our Terrablades can't shoot into honey to store a large pile of projectiles together for one big burst? Losing these quirky emergent features wasn't worth the great new graphics for the Terrablade and related swords. I said before that all the great free updates were a blessing from a developer who didn't owe us anything, and I made it a point to mention that the longevity of the udpate cycle meant more great changes that made the game into a package ever more worthy of praise...but good things don't persist when they are constantly reconfigured, like a Ship of Theseus, until they're something else entirely. At some point, you need to stop changing old things, or else they'll be lost. SEGA made this mistake gravely with PSO2's fifth episode. Let's not repeat their error.

Review: This game saved my life.  I am 41.  My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.  When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.  After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.  Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.  After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.  Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.  I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.  Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.
